  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Paul C. Small and Joselene S.
Small,        Plaintiffs,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Nicole C. Piper,       
Defendant,
Nicole D. Kane Piper f/k/a Nicole Denise Weaver,       
Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Robert Eugene Weaver and Joselene S. Small,       
Defendants,
And Joselene S. Small,       
Cross-Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Curtis Piper,       
Cross-Defendant,
Of Whom Joselene S. Small is the       
Appellant.
And Nicole C. Piper and Curtis Piper are the       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-407
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed June 
  23, 2004
Revised & Refiled September 10, 
  2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED


  
    
      
John D. Elliott, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Nicole and Curtis Piper of York, Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Joselene S. Small appeals the family courtâ€™s order requiring 
  her to pay one-half of the guardian ad litemâ€™s (Guardianâ€™s) fees, one-half of 
  the guardianâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees, and a substantial portion of Nicole and Curtis 
  Piperâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
  [1]   
FACTS
Nicole Piper and Robert Weaver were divorced in 1993.Â  Piper was 
  granted custody of the partiesâ€™ two minor children with visitation rights for 
  Weaver.Â  In 1996, Weaverâ€™s visitation was restricted to permit visits only under 
  the supervision of the childrenâ€™s paternal grandparents, Joselene and Paul Small.Â  
  Later that year, Weaver was incarcerated and the family court issued a temporary 
  order allowing the Smalls to continue visitation.Â  The Smalls exercised this 
  visitation until Weaver was released from prison in 1997.Â  Afterward, Weaver 
  resumed visitation supervised by the Smalls.Â  
In 2000, Piper brought this action against Weaver and Joselene Small 
  to suspend visitation.Â  Weaver and Small counterclaimed for custody and requested 
  Piper be held in contempt for refusing to allow visitation.Â  The court appointed 
  a guardian ad litem to represent the interests of the children.Â  The guardian 
  hired an attorney to represent her. 
The family courtâ€™s final order terminated Smallâ€™s visitation and 
  suspended Weaverâ€™s pending a determination if it would be in the best interest 
  of the children for his visits to resume.Â  The court also found Piperâ€™s decision 
  to stop the visitation was not contemptuous.Â  The order required Small and Piper 
  to each pay one-half of the fee awarded to the guardian and one-half of the 
  guardianâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The court also required Small to pay a substantial 
  portion of attorneyâ€™s fees incurred by Piper and her husband.Â  
DISCUSSION
In appeals from the 
  family court, we may find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence. Â This broad scope of review does not, however, require us to 
  disregard the findings of the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses 
  and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative 
  weight to their testimony.Â  Hollar v. Hollar, 342 S.C. 463, 472, 536 
  S.E.2d 883, 887 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
I.Â  Guardianâ€™s 
  Authority to Hire an Attorney
Small contends the family court 
  erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to the guardianâ€™s attorney, arguing the guardian 
  improperly retained counsel without obtaining prior authorization from the family 
  court.Â  We disagree.
At the time this case 
  was before the family court, there was no requirement for a guardian to seek 
  prior approval from the court before retaining counsel. [2] Â  However, Rule 12, SCRFC provides that â€œ[i]f a guardian ad 
  litem is represented by an attorney, the court in its discretion may assess 
  reasonable attorneysâ€™ fees and costs.â€Â  Accordingly, if the guardian ad litem 
  did not seek and obtain prior approval from the court for the hiring of an attorney, 
  then the guardian assumed the risk that the court might not allow a fee.Â  In 
  this case, the court subsequently approved the attorneyâ€™s hiring and awarded 
  modified fees, exercising its inherent power to protect the best interests of 
  the children and its discretionary authority under Rule 12.Â  
After Small complained in a pre-trial 
  motion that counsel for the guardian was not authorized, the court responded 
  by issuing an order requiring the guardianâ€™s attorney to participate in the 
  action.Â  In the final order, the court addressed Smallâ€™s concern directly, stating:

In making this award, 
  the Court is cognizant of the fact that the Guardian ad Litem retained 
  [counsel] without prior approval of the Court.Â  It should be noted that a Guardian 
  ad Litem will not in all instances be awarded attorneyâ€™s fees unless the Court 
  has approved the appointment of such an attorney.Â  The Court has decided to 
  award an attorneyâ€™s fee . . . because the issue of whether or not he was to 
  be involved in this case has been dealt with in a pre-trial motion by [Smallâ€™s] 
  attorney.Â  After that motion, the Order issued did not relieve [counsel] of 
  his duties but, to the contrary, gave [him] [a specific duty] . . . . [T]he 
  Court has come to the conclusion that [counselâ€™s] involvement in this case was 
  necessary and that he did so as an advocate for the best interest of the children.

In light of the family courtâ€™s 
  requirement that the guardianâ€™s counsel participate in the case and the final 
  order stating his involvement was necessary, we conclude the court did not abuse 
  its discretion in making an award.Â  
A guardian 
  ad litem is entitled to compensation for his services and reimbursement for 
  necessary expenses.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Hyatt, 
  277 S.C. 152, 154, 283 S.E.2d 445, 446 (1981).Â  â€œIn fixing the amount of compensation 
  to be paid to a guardian ad litem, a court should consider the 
  character of the litigation, the issues involved, the services performed, the 
  care and diligence exhibited, and the results achieved.â€Â  Id.Â  This court 
  will not disturb the amount of a fee award to a guardian ad litem absent an 
  abuse of discretion.Â  Nash v. Byrd, 298 S.C. 530, 537, 381 S.E.2d 913, 
  917 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  Likewise, we recognize that an award for attorneyâ€™s fees 
  is left to the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 
  415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988).
In a temporary 
  order, the family court required Small, Piper, and Weaver to each contribute 
  $700 toward the guardianâ€™s anticipated fees and costs.Â  The $2,100 was paid 
  into the trust account of Weaverâ€™s attorney who was to pay the guardianâ€™s bills 
  unless one of the parties objected.Â  The guardian was required to provide copies 
  of her monthly billing statements to each of the parties.Â  
Weaverâ€™s attorney paid 
  the guardianâ€™s first invoice in full.Â  There is no evidence in the record to 
  indicate Small objected to this initial payment.Â  The guardian submitted three 
  more bills that remained unpaid at the time of the final order.Â  
In its final order, the family 
  court awarded the guardian additional fees and costs of $2,395.30 based on the 
  last three unpaid invoices, and attorneyâ€™s fees of $6,348.40.Â  The court also 
  approved the previously paid invoice of $1,531.20 as billed. [3] Â  Small was required to pay one-half 
  of the additional fee awarded to the guardian and one-half of the guardianâ€™s 
  attorneyâ€™s fees, for a total of $4,371.85.Â  
In making the 
  fee award to the guardian, the court reduced her hourly rate by $10 from the 
  amount requested.Â  The court made the reduction after considering the absence 
  of overhead and other business expenses, as well as the intensity and urgency 
  of the work required.Â  The court stated it reviewed the entire file as well 
  as the guardianâ€™s bills and concluded all of the billed time was compensable 
  and was necessarily spent fulfilling duties and acting in the best interest 
  of the children.Â  The family court noted the guardian worked with speed and 
  diligence and had, through her efforts to promptly secure court-ordered psychological 
  evaluations, moved the case toward a timely resolution.Â  Finally, the court 
  expressly noted it had â€œtaken into consideration to a large extent the financial 
  condition of the parties . . . and the other fees and expenses each must necessarily 
  pay as a result of the litigation.â€Â  The family court relied upon the detailed 
  invoices submitted by the guardian and considered all relevant factors when 
  making the compensation award.Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of discretion 
  in the amount of the fee awarded.Â  
The court also found 
  the guardian would not have been able to effectively fulfill her duty as an 
  advocate for the best interest of the children without the assistance of counsel.Â  
  However, in making the award of attorneyâ€™s fees, the court reduced counselâ€™s 
  hourly rate substantially, from $150 to $90 per hour based on:Â  1) the relative 
  inability of the parties to pay the approximately $10,500 fee requested in his 
  affidavit and billing statement; 2) application of the factors outlined in Glasscock 
  v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991), including an evaluation 
  of the difficulty of the case; and 3) findings that a significant amount of 
  counselâ€™s billed time arose from hearings that required minimal participation 
  and preparation.Â  Finally, the court granted the parties six months from the 
  date of the order to pay the attorneyâ€™s fees or make arrangements for terms 
  with the guardianâ€™s counsel.Â  The court relied upon the affidavit of counsel 
  and adequately considered the Glasscock factors.Â  Therefore, we find 
  no abuse of discretion in the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees awarded.Â  
III.Â  Award of 
  Attorneyâ€™s Fees and Costs to Nicole and Curtis Piper
Finally, Small contends the family 
  court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to Nicole and Curtis Piper 
  without making specific findings to support the awards and without properly 
  considering the Glasscock factors.Â  Small also argues the family court 
  should have considered her ability to pay.Â  We agree.Â  
When a court decides 
  whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees it should consider the partiesâ€™ ability to 
  pay their own fees, the beneficial results obtained by counsel, the respective 
  financial conditions of the parties, and the effect of the fee award on each 
  partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 
  415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  When the court sets the amount of the fee award, 
  it must also consider the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered, 
  the time necessarily devoted to the case, counselâ€™s professional standing, the 
  contingency of compensation, the beneficial results obtained, and the customary 
  legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock, 304 S.C. at 161, 403 S.E.2d 
  at 315.Â  It is insufficient for a court to make a general reference to these 
  requirements without more.Â  If there is inadequate evidentiary support for the 
  factors to be considered in making such an award, the appellate court should 
  reverse and remand for the family court to make specific findings.Â  Haselden 
  v. Haselden, 347 S.C. 48, 66, 552 S.E.2d 329, 338 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
The family court awarded the 
  Pipers a total of $13,619 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  The order required 
  Small to make full payment in equal monthly installments within thirty-six months 
  beginning sixty days from the date of the final order.Â  In making the award, 
  the court did not consider the factors enunciated in E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 
  307 S.C. at 476-77, 415 S.E.2d at 816.Â  Moreover, the court failed to make any 
  specific findings under Glasscock, stating only that the award was made 
  â€œafter considering all requirements of the Glasscock case.â€Â  
We recognize Nicole 
  Piper prevailed in her claim for termination of Smallâ€™s visitation and successfully 
  defended against Smallâ€™s cross-claims.Â  We are also aware the family court concluded 
  Curtis Piper was, contrary to Smallâ€™s contentions, a fit and proper parent.Â  
  However, the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to the Pipers fails to take into consideration 
  Smallâ€™s ability to pay the amounts awarded and is not supported by specific 
  findings of fact.Â  
Under the terms of the order, 
  Small is required to pay a total ofÂ  $20,055.35 in fees and costs.Â  According 
  to her financial declaration, her own attorneyâ€™s fees exceeded $19,000.Â  She 
  and her husband are retired and live on a combined gross annual income of $27,360.Â  
  Smallâ€™s personal retirement income nets slightly over $1,000 per month.Â  Even 
  with the payment schedules established by the order, Small is required to pay 
  the psychologist and guardian approximately $3,000 immediately.Â  She then has 
  a six-month grace period to arrange payment terms with the guardianâ€™s counsel 
  for payment of the additional $3,174.20.Â  Sixty days after the date of the final 
  order, she is required to start making at least thirty-six equal monthly payments 
  of $377.77 to satisfy her portion of the Pipersâ€™ attorneyâ€™s fees. [4] Â  In light of these facts, we conclude the additional 
  attorneyâ€™s fees awarded to the Pipers requires analysis under the E.D.M. 
  v. T.A.M. factors.Â  We further find the family court failed to properly 
  consider the Glasscock factors when setting the amount of the award.Â  
  Accordingly, we reverse and remand this issue with specific instructions to 
  allow additional evidence on the issue of the appropriateness and amount of 
  attorneyâ€™s fees and to make specific findings of fact as to each of the six 
  Glasscock factors. 
CONCLUSION
We find the family court properly 
  approved of the guardianâ€™s decision to obtain counsel, and affirm the award 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We also affirm the amount of fees awarded to both the guardian 
  and her counsel.Â  We reverse the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Nicole and Curtis 
  Piper and remand this issue for re-determination under the factors enunciated 
  in Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991), 
  and E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  

 AFFIRMED IN PART, 
  REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and 
  CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In 2002, the legislature passed the South Carolina Guardian 
    Ad Litem Reform Act.Â  The Act was codified into law in January 2003 and is 
    not applicable to this case.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-1545 to 20-7-1557 
    (Supp. 2003).

 
   
    [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The guardian received total compensation of $3,926.50.Â  This 
    was $902 less than the total amount of her invoices.Â  

 
   
    [4] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We are unable to determine the Pipersâ€™ financial condition, 
    ability to pay their own attorneyâ€™s fees, or the effect of payment on their 
    standard of living because, contrary to the index listing, the record does 
    not contain their financial declaration.Â  In its place is a financial declaration 
    for Paul Small.Â

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-461
  Submitted September 14, 2004 â€“ Filed September 15, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED

 
   
     
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
          all of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, 
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Julian Ab Romero pled guilty to common law robbery.Â  The 
  trial court sentenced him to imprisonment for thirteen and half years.Â  Romero 
  appeals, arguing his sentence is so disproportionate to the offense it constitutes 
  unconstitutional cruel and unusual punishment.Â  On appeal, Romeroâ€™s counsel 
  filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), 
  asserting the appeal is without legal merit sufficient to warrant a new trial 
  and requesting permission to withdraw from further representation of Romero.Â  
  Romero has not filed a pro se brief. Â Â We find Romeroâ€™s appeal 
  to be without merit.
Section 16-11-325 of the South Carolina Code states, upon conviction of common 
  law robbery, â€œa person must be imprisoned not more than fifteen years.â€Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-325 (2003).Â  Generally, if a statute fixing the punishment 
  for an offense is not unconstitutional, a sentence within the limits prescribed 
  by such statute will not be regarded as cruel and unusual.Â  State v. Kimbrough, 
  212 S.C. 348, 354, 46 S.E.2d 273, 275-76 (1948).Â  This presumption of validity 
  places the heavy burden on an appellant of persuading this court that the sentence 
  is without justification and â€œshocks the collective conscience of our society.â€Â  
  Stockton v. Leeke, 269 S.C. 459, 237 S.E.2d 896 (1977).
Romeroâ€™s rather conclusory arguments fail to satisfy this hefty burden.Â  Although 
  the victimâ€™s property was eventually recovered, Romero used extreme violence 
  to forcibly obtain the property.Â  Furthermore, he has an extensive prior record, 
  including convictions for larceny, assault, DUI, aggravated sexual battery, 
  and â€œlesser homicide.â€Â  Despite these factors, the trial judge still did not 
  give Romero the maximum sentence allowed by the statute (15 years).Â  There is 
  no merit to Romeroâ€™s argument.
After a thorough review of the record and counselâ€™s brief pursuant to Anders 
  and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss 
  Romeroâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved. 
  [1]  
APPEAL DISMISSED. [2] 
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


 
   [1]  Six months prior to the hearing, a trial judge 
    ordered a psychological evaluation of Romero pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
    44-23-410 (2002), specifically to the issue of his capacity to stand trial.Â  
    Although the order calling for this evaluation is included in Romeroâ€™s record 
    on appeal, no written record or mention of the evaluationâ€™s results or a subsequent 
    capacity hearing is included.Â  Therefore, we have no way of knowing whether 
    or not Romero was found competent to stand trial.Â  Romeroâ€™s counsel vaguely 
    alluded to Romeroâ€™s mental capacity before the trial court, but did not adequately 
    raise the issue by objection when allowing Romero to enter his guilty plea.Â  
    Although troubled by the lack of any mention of the evaluationâ€™s results in 
    the record, the proper avenue in which to challenge a guilty plea which is 
    not objected to at the time of its entry is not on appeal, but through post 
    conviction relief.Â  In the interest of Antonio H., 324 S.C. 120, 122, 
    477 S.E.2d 713, 714 (1996).

 
   [2]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

  Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

  Submitted September 14, 2004 â€“ Filed September 15, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED

 
   
     
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster,Â  Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh,Â  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
          of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Mr. Green appeals after pleading guilty 
  to assault with the intent to kill (AWIK), and two counts of pointing and/or 
  presenting a firearm.Â  The trial court sentenced him to eight years on the AWIK 
  charge and five years suspended on time served and three years probation on 
  the presenting charges.Â  On appeal, Green argues his guilty plea failed to comply 
  with the requirements set forth in Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969).Â  
  Pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), Greenâ€™s counsel 
  attached a petition to be relieved stating that he has reviewed the record and 
  found the appeal to be without merit.Â  Green did not file a separate pro 
  se brief.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED

Opinion No. 2004-UP-471
  Submitted September 14, 2004 â€“Filed September 16, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Arthur K. Aiken, of Columbia, for Appellant.
      
        D. Randolph Whitt, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  This is a mortgage foreclosure 
  action.Â  Katharine Brown appeals from the master-in-equityâ€™s order finding she 
  â€œfailed to meet her burden of proof in establishing any defense to the foreclosure 
  action.â€Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
On September 29, 1995, Brown executed and delivered a promissory note to Ford 
  Consumer Finance Company, Inc. (Ford), the predecessor in interest of Ocwen 
  Federal Savings Bank, FSB (Ocwen).Â  Pursuant to the note, Brown promised to 
  pay to Ford the principal sum of $41,676, with interest at the rate of 13.10 
  percent per annum.Â  The note was secured by a mortgage given by Brown to Ford 
  covering property located at 149 Crane Creek Drive in Richland County.Â  The 
  mortgage was thereafter assigned to Ocwen.
Ocwen instituted this action against Brown seeking a foreclosure of the mortgage 
  and a sale of the property.Â  â€œAssociates Financial Serv., Richland Memorial 
  Hosp/Charles Hallman, Sun Finance and Ford Motor Credit Companyâ€ were made parties 
  by virtue of the fact that they may have or claim to have some right, title, 
  interest in or lien upon the real property as judgment creditors.Â  Brown was 
  â€œ[t]he titleholder[] of record of the . . . propertyâ€ to be foreclosed.Â  An 
  order compelling discovery responses required Brown to produce any evidence 
  she had of payment on the note and mortgage by April 9, 2002.
The master-in-equity held a foreclosure hearing.Â  The master found the note 
  and mortgage were in default and ordered foreclosure of the mortgage and sale 
  of the subject property at public auction.Â  Further, the master determined the 
  â€œ[p]rincipal amount due as of April 22, 2002â€ was $41,200.08, with interest 
  â€œfrom June 4, 1998 to June 17, 2002 at the rate of 13.10 [percent] per annumâ€ 
  totaling $22,067.03.Â  The Judgment of Foreclosure and Sale was dated July 11, 
  2002, and filed on July 16, 2002.
On August 2, 2002, Brown filed a motion to alter 
  or amend judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  In the motion, Brown asserted 
  the judgment â€œshould be altered or amended to make a finding of a failure to 
  comply with the attorney preference requirementâ€ because she â€œpresented uncontested 
  evidence that the Plaintiffâ€™s predecessor-in-interest, Ford Motor Credit Corporation, 
  failed to advise her of her right to select her own attorney.â€Â  At the hearing, 
  counsel for Brown noted: â€œ[T]he order did not address specifically the preference 
  issues.Â  And thatâ€™s what we would like to have altered or amended, that portion 
  of the judgment, so that it specifically addresses the preference issues.â€Â  
  The master granted Brownâ€™s motion to alter or amend the judgment to include 
  his decision regarding the attorney preference issue.
The subject property was sold at foreclosure sale 
  on August 5, 2002.Â  An order confirming the sale was filed on November 26, 2002.Â  
  Brownâ€™s second motion to alter or amend the judgment of foreclosure and sale 
  was dated December 6, 2002.Â  Brown based â€œthis motion upon the grounds that 
  she has previously taken the position that she has paid the mortgage [in full] 
  in this case, and that she has now presented documentary evidence to support 
  that position.â€Â  Brown averred the foreclosure should not â€œhave gone forward, 
  and therefore she is entitled to have it essentially unraveled and to put the 
  property back for sale.â€Â  This motion was denied by order dated January 29, 
  2003, and filed on February 6, 2003.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action to foreclose a real 
  estate mortgage is an action in equity.Â  Hayne Fed. Credit Union v. Bailey, 
  327 S.C. 242, 489 S.E.2d 472 (1997); Swindler v. Swindler, 355 S.C. 245, 
  584 S.E.2d 438 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  On appeal from an action in equity, this court 
  is not required to disregard the findings of the master.Â  BB & T v. Kidwell, 
  350 S.C. 382, 565 S.E.2d 316 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The master, who saw and heard 
  the witnesses, was in a better position to assess their credibility and the 
  weight that should be given to their testimony.Â  See Jocoy v. Jocoy, 
  349 S.C. 441, 562 S.E.2d 674 (Ct. App. 2002) (explaining that while the standard 
  of review in equity cases permits an appellate court a broad scope of review, 
  the court does not disregard the findings of the master-in-equity, who saw and 
  heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility).Â  
  However, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 498 S.E.2d 862 (1998); 
  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 
  (1976).
LAW
Defense of Payment
Brown argues the master-in-equity erred in finding she â€œhad not paid the balance 
  on the note and mortgage in full.â€Â  We disagree.
Brown claims she presented evidence that demonstrates she â€œhad paid at least 
  a substantial portion of this balance due.â€Â  Brown contended she â€œcould not 
  present the remainder of the documents demonstrating that the note and mortgage 
  had been paid in full, because her documents were lost after an agent for Ocwen 
  had secured her premises.â€Â  These assertions are meritless.
The documents Brown presented 
  showed payments which added up to substantially less than the amount of the 
  debt.Â  Brownâ€™s submission included a document evidencing a $6,000 payment which 
  occurred in 1987, approximately eight years before the execution of the note 
  and mortgage involved in the present action.Â  Brownâ€™s self-serving, conclusory 
  statement that she paid the note and mortgage in full was not supported by the 
  evidence.Â  Brownâ€™s evidence does not prove she paid the debt in full, but shows 
  Brown still has an arrearage.Â  Moreover, Brown had ample time after the discovery 
  requests seeking her evidence of payment and the subsequent order to compel 
  discovery to obtain duplicates of any lost documentation.
The master correctly found that Brown failed to meet her burden of proof â€œin 
  establishing any defense to the foreclosure action.â€
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the decision of the master-in-equity is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

v.
Spencer Lockard, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
William J. Wylie, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 2004-UP-475
Heard September 14, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  September 16, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert N. Rosen, of Charleston, for Appellant.
John Loy, of Summerville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:  In this domestic relations 
  matter, Spencer Lockard (Husband) contends the family court erred in (1) failing 
  to award joint custody of the two children; (2) granting inadequate visitation 
  to Husband; and (3) awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Linda Lockard (Wife).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Husbandâ€™s marriage to Wife lasted about thirteen 
  years, during which time the couple produced two sons: Spencer Lee Lockard, 
  II, born April 15, 1990, and Bradford Parks Lockard, born July 6, 1993.Â  Throughout 
  the childrenâ€™s younger years, Wife stayed at home and acted as their primary 
  caretaker while Husband worked.Â  As the children grew, Husbandâ€™s lifelong anger 
  problems and belief in strict discipline began to undermine the partiesâ€™ marriage.Â  
  Though the couple sought to repair their broken relationship through marriage 
  counseling, the effort ultimately proved fruitless.
As a consequence of the ongoing problems, Wife 
  filed for divorce on April 11, 2001, seeking custody of the partiesâ€™ two minor 
  children.Â  Husband filed an answer and counterclaim requesting sole custody 
  of the children, or in the alternative, joint custody.Â  Prior to a final hearing 
  on the merits, the family court entered a temporary order awarding Husband and 
  Wife joint physical custody of the children, with custody alternating every 
  two weeks in the marital home.
During the final hearing before the family court, 
  testimony was presented as to several occasions when Husband lost control of 
  his anger, acting aggressively toward Wife and others.Â  Although Husband admitted 
  he had problems with his temper, he elicited testimony from other witnesses 
  to show the temporary joint custody arrangement had been a boon to the childrenâ€™s 
  maturation and well-being.Â  By final order and decree of divorce entered September 
  13, 2002, the family court awarded Wife custody of the children and granted 
  Husband â€œstandard visitationâ€ with restrictions.Â  The court also awarded Wife 
  $10,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Custody
Husband contends the family court erred â€œby failing 
  to award the Husband and Wife 50/50 joint physical custodyâ€ of the children.Â  
  We disagree.
On appeal from the family court, this court has 
  jurisdiction to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence. Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 
  244-45 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  This tribunal, however, is not required to disregard 
  the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 202, 522 
  S.E.2d 835, 838 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Likewise, we are not obligated to ignore the 
  fact the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better 
  position to evaluate their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 
  91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œBecause this court is not afforded 
  the opportunity for direct observation of the witnesses, we must accord great 
  deference to the trial courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility are involved.â€Â  
  Pountain v. Pountain, 332 S.C. 130, 135, 503 S.E.2d 757, 760-61 (Ct. 
  App. 1998).Â  â€œThis is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best 
  interests of children.â€Â  Id. at 135, 503 S.E.2d at 761.
In child custody controversies, the welfare and 
  best interests of the children are the primary, paramount, and controlling considerations 
  of the court.Â  Cook v. Cobb, 271 S.C. 136, 140, 245 S.E.2d 612, 614 (1978).Â  
  The family court must consider the character, fitness, attitude, and inclinations 
  on the part of each parent as they impact the child.Â  Pountain, 332 S.C. 
  at 136, 503 S.E.2d at 760.Â  Moreover, in reaching a determination as to custody, 
  the family court should consider how the custody decision will impact all areas 
  of the childâ€™s life, including physical, psychological, spiritual, educational, 
  familial, emotional, and recreational aspects.Â  Kisling v. Allison, 343 
  S.C. 674, 678-79, 541 S.E.2d 273, 275 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Indeed, in making custody 
  decisions, â€œthe totality of circumstances peculiar to each case constitutes 
  the only scale upon which the ultimate decision can be weighed.â€Â  Davenport 
  v. Davenport, 265 S.C. 524, 527, 220 S.E.2d 228, 230 (1975).
In view of the totality of the circumstances that 
  must be considered, we remain mindful that joint custody should only be ordered 
  under exceptional circumstances.Â  See Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 
  118, 125, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003) (stating that â€œâ€˜divided custody is usually 
  harmful to and not conducive to the best interest and welfare of the childrenâ€™â€).Â  
  Given our courtsâ€™ well-considered reluctance toward awarding joint custody, 
  we find the family court did not err in declining to award joint custody in 
  the case at bar.Â  Indeed, the family courtâ€™s decision finds ample support in 
  the record.Â  Husbandâ€™s frequent outbursts of anger and repeated efforts to minimize 
  Wifeâ€™s relationship with the children provide ample reasons for declining to 
  award such a heavily disfavored form of custody.
II.Â  Visitation
In the alternative, Husband asserts the family 
  court erred in awarding Husband less than â€œstandardâ€ visitation.Â  We disagree.
When awarding visitation, the controlling 
  consideration is the welfare and best interest of the child.Â  Woodall v. 
  Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 12, 471 S.E.2d 154, 158 (1996).Â  As with child custody, 
  the issue of child visitation falls within the discretion of the trial judge, 
  and his findings will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  
  Id.Â  The original Final Order and Decree of Divorce issued by the family 
  court awarded Husband two weeks of summer visitation.Â  However, the Final Order 
  and Decree of Divorce was supplemented and amended in an order dated November 
  12, 2002, providing:
Visitation shall be amended to include:

  
    
      
        a. 
         Two (2) additional weeks of summer visitation, 
  for a total of four (4) weeks summer visitation for the Father.
      
      
        b.   
         Weekday visitation during the off week for the Father.
      
      
        c.   
         Visitation on each childâ€™s birthday.
      
      
        d.   
        Telephone visitation for
          either parent, without interference.
      
    
  

The record reveals nothing indicating the family 
  court strayed beyond its discretionary authority in awarding Husband four weeks 
  of summer visitation.
III.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband maintains that, if he is successful on the 
  joint custody issue, he should not have to pay Wife $10,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
  We affirmed the family courtâ€™s determination regarding custody.Â  Thus, Husband 
  did not prevail on the custody issue.Â  Alternatively, Husband asserts that the 
  family court abused its discretion in awarding Wife $10,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees will not be overturned 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 
  415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988).Â  Before awarding attorneyâ€™s fees, the family 
  court should consider: (1) each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee; (2) 
  the beneficial results obtained by the attorney; (3) the partiesâ€™ respective 
  financial conditions; and (4) the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partyâ€™s 
  standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 
  812, 816 (1992); Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 160, 543 S.E.2d 224, 231 
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In determining the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the 
  court should consider: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services 
  rendered; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) counselâ€™s professional 
  standing; (4) the contingency of compensation; (5) the beneficial results obtained; 
  and (6) the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 
  304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991); Shirley v. Shirley, 342 
  S.C. 324, 341, 536 S.E.2d 427, 436 (Ct. App. 2000).
Having reviewed the award of attorneyâ€™s fees 
  in light of the applicable factors, we find no abuse of discretion in the award.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the order of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, JJ., 
  concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  In this banking dispute brought 
  by Respondent Wachovia Bank to collect on an outstanding note, Appellants Winona 
  Grain Company and Michael Brittonâ€”the noteâ€™s borrower and guarantor, respectivelyâ€”challenge 
  the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of their counterclaim against Wachovia.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
In late 1997, Michael Britton, the principal manager 
  of Winona Grain Company, a corporation in the business of buying and selling 
  grain, met with Darren Bouknight, a loan officer for Wachovia Bank, to acquire 
  capital for operating the business.Â  Through Bouknight, the bank agreed to extend 
  two lines of credit to Winona, one in the amount of $750,000.00 and the other 
  in the amount of $75,000.00.Â  
Wachovia secured the larger line of credit through 
  a first priority lien on Winonaâ€™s South Carolina Department of Agriculture warehouse 
  grain receipts and capped the amount of credit available to 80% of the value 
  of the receipts.Â  To maintain this 80% margin, the loanâ€™s commitment letter 
  allowed Wachovia to demand partial repayment anytime grain devaluation caused 
  the balance owed on the loan to exceed 80% of the value of the grain receipts.Â  
  If Wachovia made such a demand, the commitment letter gave Winona five business 
  days to bring the amounts back within the 80% margin requirement.Â  Though the 
  smaller line of credit had no corresponding margin requirement, Wachovia secured 
  the smaller loan through a â€œ[c]ontinuing first security interest in all non-receipted 
  grain inventory, inventory, accounts receivable, and assignment of grain trading 
  Margin Account.â€Â  
The commitment letters for both loans contained 
  cross-default clauses and established April 30, 1999 as the date when the lines 
  of credit expired.Â  The commitment letters also contained the following terms:

Prepayment: 
Both Notes â€“ At your companyâ€™s election, your company 
  may prepay these Loans in whole or part without penalty.
. . . .
Disbursement and Conditions:
Both Notes â€“ Funds are to be distributed to Winona Grain 
  Co. Inc.â€™s business checking account at Wachovia Bank, N.A.
. . . . 
The provisions of the commitment shall survive the Loan closing 
  and shall be incorporated in the Loan documents so that a default by the Borrower 
  of any such provision shall constitute a default under the Loan documents.

More than a week after agreeing to the terms of 
  the commitment letters, Winona executed a Note and Security Agreement for both 
  revolving lines of credit using the bankâ€™s standard forms.Â  Both notes specifically 
  incorporated the terms and conditions contained in the commitment letters and 
  indicated the loans were due on demand.Â  The notes also included the following 
  provision:

In addition, to the extent not prohibited by law, the Borrower 
  hereby grants to the Lender a security interest in and security title to, and 
  does hereby assign, pledge, transfer and convey to Lender . . . any balance 
  or deposit accounts of the Borrower, whether such accounts be general or special, 
  or individual or multiple party, and upon all drafts, notes, or other items 
  deposited for collection or presented for payment by the Borrower with the Lender, 
  and the Lender may at any time, without demand or notice, appropriate and apply 
  any of such to the payment of any of the Obligations (except for Restricted 
  Debt), whether or not due.

In the months following execution of the 
  notes, Wachovia dispersed the requested funds from both lines of credit into 
  Winonaâ€™s business checking account.Â  At some time in August, Bouknight telephoned 
  Britton to tell him to deposit funds into Winonaâ€™s account to cover checks that 
  had been presented for payment against the account that day.Â  Though Britton 
  responded by making a deposit into Winonaâ€™s checking account, the deposit came 
  in the form of an out-of-state check and was thus subject to Wachoviaâ€™s five-day 
  hold policy for out-of-state checks.Â  As a consequence, the checks that prompted 
  Bouknightâ€™s telephone call were returned for insufficient funds.Â  
In October of 1998, because Winona had 
  not given the South Carolina Department of Agriculture their audited financial 
  statements, the Department withheld validation of Winonaâ€™s warehouse receipts.Â  
  Although Winonaâ€™s receipts lacked Department validation, Bouknight agreed to 
  advance funds to Winona on the grain under the trust receipts.Â  Thus, while 
  Winona collected the financial records required for Department validation, Wachovia 
  made advancements of $40,000.00, $15,000.00, $75,000.00, and $8,000.00, with 
  respective due dates of October 29, October 31, November 2, and November 5, 
  1998.Â  
On November 3, 1998, after the expiration 
  dates for the first three trust receipts passed with no repayment from Winona, 
  Wachovia applied $16,684.10 of Winonaâ€™s checking account against the larger 
  line of credit.Â  Again on November 4, Wachovia applied an additional $21,042.06 
  of Winonaâ€™s account against the larger line of credit.Â  Over the same two days, 
  Wachovia returned 12 checks on Winonaâ€™s account unpaid.Â  
On November 12, 1998, the Department of Agriculture 
  validated Winonaâ€™s warehouse receipts, thereby providing adequate security for 
  the larger line of credit.Â  Shortly thereafter, with the loan no longer under-collateralized, 
  Wachovia made advancements of $145,000.00 and $300,000.00 on the larger line 
  of credit, though Wachovia applied $45,000.00 of the advanced funds against 
  the outstanding amount on the smaller line of credit.Â  
Over the next two months, Wachovia returned 19 checks on 
  Winonaâ€™s account for insufficient funds.Â  Thereafter, Wachovia brought this 
  action against Winona for claim and delivery and recovery on the notes.Â  Wachovia 
  also sought to recover against Britton on his personal guarantee.Â  Winona asserted 
  setoff as a defense and counterclaimed for wrongful dishonor of checks presented 
  for payment against Winonaâ€™s checking account.Â  
Prior to the trial on the merits, the trial court 
  granted Wachoviaâ€™s motion for summary judgment on its claims against Winona 
  and Britton for the balance due on the notes in the amount of $54,916.75.Â  With 
  only Winonaâ€™s counterclaims remaining, a trial was commenced before a jury on 
  November 18, 2002.Â  After Winona presented its evidence, Wachovia moved for 
  directed verdict.Â  After hearing argument, the trial court granted Wachoviaâ€™s 
  directed verdict motion as to all causes of action.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Motions for directed verdict require the trial 
  judge to view the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  
  This court will reverse the trial court only when there is no evidence to support 
  the ruling below. Steinke v. South Carolina Dept. of Labor, Licensing and 
  Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 520 S.E.2d 142 (1999).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

  I.      Wrongful Dishonor

Winona contends the trial court erred in directing 
  a verdict against its counterclaim for wrongful dishonor because the loan agreement 
  with Wachovia was ambiguous and unconscionable.Â  We disagree.
A bank owes a general duty to each customer to 
  honor checks drawn on his or her account if the customerâ€™s account has sufficient 
  funds to cover the item presented.Â  St. Charles Mercantile Co. v. Armour 
  & Co., 156 S.C. 397, 405, 153 S.E. 473, 477 (1930) (â€œIt was the duty 
  of the bank, when a check which properly demanded payment was presented, to 
  make payment, if the drawer had sufficient funds to meet it.â€).Â  Rather than 
  contending the companyâ€™s checking account had sufficient funds to cover each 
  of the dishonored checks, Winona argues that the accountâ€™s reoccurring insufficiencies 
  were due to Wachoviaâ€™s improper conduct, not its own.Â  
Specifically, Winona argues Wachovia was required 
  to immediately credit Winonaâ€™s account for all deposits, and when Wachovia placed 
  a five-day hold on the deposit of an out-of-state check for $80,000.00, Wachovia 
  wrongfully caused an insufficiency that resulted in two checks being returned 
  on August 10, 1998.Â  To support their position that Wachovia was bound to give 
  immediate credit for all depositsâ€”a requirement not found in the loan documentsâ€”Winona 
  contends that because Wachovia had previously given Winona immediate credit 
  on deposits, they established a course of dealing that Wachovia was bound to 
  continue.Â  This argument finds no support in our law.Â  Courts do not look to 
  the course of dealing between parties as a tool for inserting new obligations 
  among those made explicit by the terms of a written agreement.Â  Rather, courts 
  draw upon partiesâ€™ dealings only when necessary to acquire an improved understand 
  of the meaning the parties intended by using particular words or expressions 
  in a subsequent written agreement.Â  Thus, course of dealing evidence is used 
  to aid to contract interpretation, not to show contract augmentation.Â  See 
  Columbia Nitrogen Corp. v. Royster Co., 451 F.2d 3, 9 (4th Cir. 1971) 
  (â€œ[E]vidence of usage of trade and course of dealing should be excluded whenever 
  it cannot be reasonably construed as consistent with the terms of the contract.â€); 
  Wolfe v. Herlihy, 218 S.C. 90, 95, 61 S.E.2d 764, 767-68 (1950) (â€œThe 
  testimony shows that this payment was tendered in full conformity with the construction 
  placed upon the ambiguous provisions of the lease by the parties themselves 
  through their long course of dealing.â€).Â  
Ambiguities or conflicts in documents constituting 
  contract must be construed against the party who prepared the contract. Mid-Continent 
  Refrigerator Co. v. Way, 263 S.C. 101, 208 S.E.2d 31 (1974); Southern 
  Atlantic Financial Services, Inc. v. Middleton, 349 S.C. 77, 562 S.E.2d 
  482 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Identical repayment provisions of both commitment letters 
  state, â€œ[b]orrower shall repay all or any part of the amount committed on such 
  dates as it may determineâ€¦â€ Winona asserts these provisions, coupled with the 
  ability to prepay without penalty, conflict with Wachoviaâ€™s right under the 
  notes to require payment at any time.Â  These two provisions, however, merely 
  allow either party to elect at any time to extinguish the debt.Â  No ambiguity 
  results from these terms.Â Â Â  
Winona also argues that 
  the court should give more weight to the typed commitment letters than to the 
  printed notes.Â  This rule, however, only applies when the documents create an 
  inconsistency and because the trial judge correctly found no ambiguity in the 
  documents, this argument is without merit.Â  See 17A Am. Jur. 2d Contracts 
  Â§ 395 (2002).
As such, even though Wachovia had immediately credited 
  previous deposits, both partiesâ€™ responsibilities and obligations remained the 
  same as outlined in their written agreement. 
Winona next argues Wachovia was required to make 
  automatic advances from the lines of credit to cover overdrafts on the Winona 
  account.Â  If Wachovia had made such automatic advances, Winona argues, the balance 
  in the checking account would have been sufficient to cover certain checks Wachovia 
  dishonored.Â  Although no written agreement between Wachovia and Winona mentions 
  automatic overdraft coverage, Winona relys exclusively on Brittonâ€™s own testimony 
  about an alleged oral agreement made with Bouknight.Â  Winonaâ€™s reliance is misplaced. 
  Â The parol evidence rule bars the introduction of extrinsic evidence to modify 
  or contradict the terms of an integrated written agreement.Â  Levy v. Outdoor 
  Resorts, 304 S.C. 427, 432, 405 S.E.2d 387, 390 (1991).Â  As a matter of 
  substantive law, therefore, Brittonâ€™s testimony cannot modify the explicit terms 
  of the partiesâ€™ written agreement.
Winona further argues that Wachovia wrongfully 
  dishonored two $30,000.00 checks that Winona drew on its account at Wachovia 
  Bank and then deposited into Winonaâ€™s account at Pee Dee Federal Savings Bank.Â  
  Winona contends that although Wachovia later tendered a cashierâ€™s check to satisfy 
  the dishonored checks, the subsequent tender did not retroactively ameliorate 
  the accountâ€™s previous insufficiency.Â  
As the forgoing makes clear, Winona has adduced 
  no evidence to show it had sufficient funds in its account to satisfy the checks 
  dishonored by Wachovia.Â  Further, Winonaâ€™s allegations of wrongdoing by Wachovia 
  all fail as a matter of law.Â  Accordingly, the trial court committed no error 
  in granting Wachoviaâ€™s directed verdict motion on Winonaâ€™s counterclaims.Â  

  II.   Â Setoff

As its final issue on appeal, Winona argues 
  the trial court erred in granting Wachoviaâ€™s motion for summary judgment because 
  the defense of setoff asserted by Winona created factual issues as to the amount 
  of indebtedness owed under the notes.Â  We disagree.
Rather than contesting facts germane to Wachoviaâ€™s 
  claim, Winona, in effect, asserts that the mere existence of its counterclaim 
  allows for the possibility of a right of setoff, thereby precluding the trial 
  court from granting summary judgment.Â  As the trial court correctly noted, â€œthe 
  mere existence of this potential right of setoff does not create a genuine issue 
  of material fact.â€Â  With no genuine dispute as to the material facts of Wachoviaâ€™s 
  claim, the trial court committed no error in granting summary judgment. 
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Thomas W. Spivey, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-483Â Â Â 
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed September 20, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John 
  W. McInitosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, and Senior 
  Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Thomas W. Spivey, Jr., appeals his conviction and sentence 
  for breach of trust with fraudulent intent.Â  He asserts the trial court erred 
  by failing to grant his motion for a directed verdict because the State failed 
  to produce substantial circumstantial evidence he was guilty of taking money 
  from his employer.Â  We affirm. [1] 
  
FACTS
  Don Cauthen hired Spivey to manage Studebakerâ€™s, a club owned by 
    Cauthen.Â  One of Spiveyâ€™s responsibilities was to verify the nightly receipts. 
    After closing, the bartenders added the receipts in their cash register, prepared 
    a deposit slip, and turned it into the manager on duty that night.Â  The manager 
    then verified the deposit slip and compared it to the register tape, which 
    the bartenders did not have access to prior to calculating their deposit slips.Â  
    The manager then took the deposit by the bank that night, and Diane Davenport, 
    the barâ€™s bookkeeper, collected the statements the following morning.
  Davenport testified that on one occasion in September 1994, she 
    collected the deposits and statement from the bank and noticed several deposit 
    slips written by bartenders that were not processed by the bank.Â  She compared 
    the slips and found slips that Spivey had written for a lesser amount, which 
    were processed by the bank.Â  The currency amount on the slip written by Spivey 
    was $150 less than the amount listed by the bartender.
  Cauthen testified that he became suspicious of Spivey and gave Richard Zecchino, 
    a bartender at Studebakerâ€™s, a $100 bill to place in one of the registers 
    on a night Spivey was working as a manager to determine if Spivey was decreasing 
    the amount on the deposit slips.Â  At the end of the night, the register should 
    have been $100 over the appropriate amount.Â  The deposit slip for that night 
    was reduced by $100.Â  Cauthen testified he confronted Spivey regarding the 
    changed deposit slips and Spivey maintained he changed them because of having 
    to move money between registers.Â  Cauthen, however, testified that none of 
    the deposit slips had been increased; only decreased.
  Cauthen also testified about the procedures employed in handling the money.Â  
    He testified that the bartender counted the money, which was then verified 
    by the manager according to the register tape.Â  If the amount was counted 
    incorrectly or was otherwise different from the tape, the bartender was notified 
    and was the only one permitted to make any changes.Â  Cauthen testified the 
    manager then took the money to the bank and made the night deposit.Â  
  State Law Enforcement Division (SLED) forensic examiner Joyce Lauterbach 
    reviewed the deposit slips from January through September 1994 and determined 
    there were 180 altered slips.Â  Using a video spectral comparator, she determined 
    the majority of the slips contained overwriting or changes from $100 to $300.Â  
    The total of the changes was found to be $17,730.Â  It was later determined 
    that Spivey was the manager on duty for all but one instance of a changed 
    deposit slip.
  Zecchino testified he counted the money in his register several times before 
    giving the money to the manager on duty.Â  He testified that if his calculations 
    were incorrect, he requested a new deposit slip and did not make any changes 
    to the one he had already written.Â  He also testified that several of his 
    deposit slips that were altered by $100 to $200 were not calculation errors 
    or mistakes.Â  Additionally, he testified the bartenders frequently did not 
    ring up drinks so the register had more money in it than the tape showed, 
    creating a buffer.Â  Finally, Zecchino testified that after he was placed in 
    charge of decreasing pour costs and making certain all drinks were accounted 
    for on the registers, Spivey told him to â€œlay off of them a little bit.â€
  At trial, Spivey moved for a directed verdict on the grounds that when viewing 
    all evidence in the light most favorable to the State, the State failed to 
    produce any evidence that he had taken any property.Â  The trial court denied 
    the motion.Â  Spivey renewed the motion at the end of trial, and the court 
    denied the motion again.
  Spivey was convicted of breach of trust with fraudulent intent and sentenced 
    to eight years, suspended on time served with five years probation.Â  The court 
    also ordered him to pay $13,000 in restitution.
  LAW/ANALYSIS

Spivey argues the
trial court erred in failing to grant his motion for a directed verdict on the
charge of breach of trust with fraudulent intent. 
He maintains the State failed to produce any direct or circumstantial
evidence to show he actually took money as opposed to simply correcting the
deposit slips.  We disagree.

In reviewing the denial of a motion for a directed verdict, we must use 
      the same standard as the trial court and view the evidence in the light 
      most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 653, 
      572 S.E.2d 267, 273 (2002).Â  The trial court is concerned with the existence 
      of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 555, 
      564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002).Â  The trial judge is required to submit the case 
      to the jury if there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial 
      evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused.Â  State 
      v. Lollis, 343 S.C. 580, 584, 541 S.E.2d 254, 256 (2001).Â  On the other 
      hand, â€œ[a] defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails 
      to produce any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence of the offense 
      charged.â€Â  State v. Rothschild, 351 S.C. 238, 243, 569 S.E.2d 346, 
      348 (2002).Â 
    Breach of trust with fraudulent intent, commonly called embezzlement in 
      other jurisdictions, has been defined as â€œlarceny after trust, which includes 
      all of the elements of larceny or in common parlance, stealing, except the 
      unlawful taking in the beginning.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-230 (Supp. 2003); 
      State v. Owings, 205 S.C. 314, 316, 31 S.E.2d 906, 907 (1944).Â  â€œThe 
      primary difference between larceny and breach of trust is that in â€˜common-law 
      larceny, possession of the property stolen is obtained unlawfully, while 
      in breach of trust, the possession is obtained lawfully.â€™â€Â  State v. 
      Scott, 330 S.C. 125, 130, 497 S.E.2d 735, 738 (Ct. App. 1998) (quoting 
      State v. McCann, 167 S.C. 393, 398, 166 S.E. 411, 413 (1932)).Â  Thus, 
      in order to prove breach of trust, the State had to prove Spivey actually 
      took money from the deposits and the appropriation was accompanied by a 
      fraudulent intent to destroy the right of the true owner, Studebakerâ€™s.
    At trial, several bartenders testified regarding their deposits.Â  
      Most notably, Zecchino testified he rarely miscounted his money and was 
      certain the amount written on his deposit slip was the same amount he gave 
      to Spivey.Â  Zecchino also testified that on specific dates he did not recall 
      being told that his count was off.Â  Finally, he testified that if he erred 
      in his calculations, he was supposed to get a new deposit slip and make 
      the change, not Spivey.
    Cauthen testified he had Zecchino put an extra one hundred dollar 
      bill in one of the registers without Spiveyâ€™s knowledge.Â  After the money 
      was counted and turned over to Spivey, the deposit slip was reduced by $100.Â  
      Cauthen also testified that it was Spiveyâ€™s duty to make the night deposits.Â  
      Finally, Davenport testified it was Spiveyâ€™s handwriting on the altered 
      deposit slips and the forensic examiner verified that there were approximately 
      180 altered slips from January through September of 1994.
    The State, therefore, presented substantial 
      circumstantial evidence that Spivey was improperly reducing the amount on 
      the deposit slips and the money in Spiveyâ€™s possession that should have 
      been included in the deposit for Studebakerâ€™s was not deposited in the bank.Â  
      Accordingly, we find the State offered substantial circumstantial evidence 
      of Spiveyâ€™s taking of money that belonged to Studebakerâ€™s and thus, the 
      trial court properly denied Spiveyâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.
    AFFIRMED.
    STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Ernest Berry Sibert, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Special Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-484Â Â Â 
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed September 20, 2004 


AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED IN PART, 
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â Â  Ernest Sibert appeals his 
  guilty pleas and an order terminating his participation in drug court, arguing 
  his pleas were involuntary and the trial court erred by terminating him from 
  drug court.Â  We affirm in part, vacate in part, and remand. [1] 
FACTS
On February 19, 2001, Sibert pled guilty to 2nd degree 
  burglary; distribution of crack, 3rd offense; and possession of crack, 
  3rd offense.Â  Sibert was sentenced to 15 years for burglary and distribution 
  of crack, and 10 years for possession of crack, all suspended upon his entry 
  into and completion of the drug court program.Â  
Sibert entered into the drug court program on February 
  19, 2001.Â  On May 16, 2002, the State sought to have Sibertâ€™s drug court participation 
  terminated for violating numerous conditions of drug court: in April 2001 he 
  made a change in annual employment and was sanctioned to visit an alcohol recovery 
  center; in September 2001 he failed to pay his fees and was sanctioned to 8 
  hours of community service; in October 2001 he twice failed to pay his fees 
  again and was sanctioned with community service and weekend duty in the detention 
  center; and in December 2001 he quit his job and was sanctioned to 16 hours 
  of community service. Additionally, while enrolled in drug court, Sibert was 
  indicted for 1st degree burglary, assault and battery of a high and aggravated 
  nature, and possession of heroin.Â  Furthermore, Sibert was served with two warrants 
  for trafficking while he was incarcerated.
In his defense, Sibert claimed he only missed one 
  of his appointments; he had not failed any of his drug tests while he was enrolled 
  in drug court; and he could not pay his weekly fees because he was only getting 
  paid every two weeks.Â  
During the May 16, 2002 termination hearing, Sibert 
  pleaded guilty to 2nd degree burglary; assault and battery of a high and aggravated 
  nature; possession of heroin; possession with intent to distribute within a 
  half mile of a school; possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine, 3rd 
  offense; distribution of crack, 3rd offense; and distribution 
  of crack within a half mile of a park.Â  
The trial court terminated Sibertâ€™s participation in 
  drug court and sentenced Sibert to concurrent sentences of 10 years on all charges 
  with the exception of 15 years for distribution of crack, 3rd offense, and 5 
  years for possession of heroin.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Sibert argues the trial court erred in terminating 
  his participation in drug court.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe nature of the inquiry and extent of the investigation 
  to be conducted by the [trial court] in determining whether the condition of 
  a suspended sentence has been violated are matters that rest in the sound discretion 
  of that court.â€Â  State v. Miller, 122 S.C. 468, 474-475, 115 S.E. 742, 
  745 (1923) (citation omitted).Â  â€œ[T]he authority of the [trial court] to revoke 
  such suspension of sentence may not be capriciously or arbitrarily exercised, 
  but should always be predicated upon an evidentiary showing of fact tending 
  to establish violation of the conditions.â€Â  Id.Â  
Our scope of review is confined to the correction 
  of errors of law, unless it appears the trial court was influenced or controlled 
  by some erroneous view of the law, was wholly without evidence to support it, 
  or amounted to a manifest abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  Otherwise, a finding 
  of fact by the trial court as to a breach of the conditions of a suspended sentence 
  is final.Â  Id.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The State presented evidence that Sibert missed 
  a case management appointment, was repeatedly late paying his required fees, 
  failed to remain employed, and was rearrested on multiple charges, including 
  possession of heroin.Â  Additionally, while Sibert was incarcerated for these 
  crimes, he was served warrants for drug trafficking.Â  Because there was sufficient 
  evidence for the trial court to determine that Sibert violated the conditions 
  of drug court, the court did not abuse its discretion in terminating Sibertâ€™s 
  participation in drug court.Â Â Â  
II.Â  Sibert contends his guilty pleas did not comply 
  with the standards set forth in Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969); 
  however, Sibert did not object to the circuit courtâ€™s accepting his guilty plea, 
  nor did he assert that his plea was involuntarily or unknowingly given.Â  Thus, 
  the issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Holy Loch Distribs., Inc. 
  v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 24, 531 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2000) (â€œIn order to 
  preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue must have been raised to and 
  ruled upon by the trial court.â€). 
III.Â  Sibert also claims that two of his pleas 
  should be vacated because he did not exercise a written waiver of presentment 
  to the grand jury.Â  We agree.
â€œBy their plain language, [South Carolina Code sections 
  17-23-130 and 140 (2003)] make a written waiver of presentment of indictments 
  not presented to a grand jury mandatory before the trial judge can accept the 
  plea. We therefore hold appellantâ€™s failure to properly execute the waivers 
  renders the pleas invalid.â€Â  Summerall v. State, 278 S.C. 255, 256, 294 
  S.E.2d 344, 344 (1982).
Thus, the pleas on the two indictments not presented 
  to the grand jury, 2002-GS-23-2852 and 2853, are vacated and the case is remanded 
  for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.Â  The pleas on the remaining 
  indictment numbers are affirmed.Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED IN PART, and REMANDED.
STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

Appeal From York County
John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-485
Submitted September 14, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  September 20, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  and Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  Anthony Rayfield was 
  indicted by the York County Grand Jury for distribution of crack cocaine (third 
  offense) and possession of crack cocaine with intent to distribute.Â  A 
  jury convicted Rayfield of both charges, and he received two concurrent prison 
  terms of eighteen years each.Â  Pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 
  U.S. 738 (1967), Rayfieldâ€™s appellate counsel filed an appeal and a petition 
  to be relieved as counsel, arguing in the Anders brief that the trial 
  court erred in consolidating the charges.Â  This court denied counselâ€™s petition 
  to be relieved and ordered the parties to brief the issue of whether, in light 
  of this courtâ€™s decision in State v. Chisolm, 355 S.C. 175, 584 S.E.2d 
  401 (Ct. App. 2003), the trial court erred in denying Rayfieldâ€™s motion to suppress 
  the crack cocaine evidence based on the ground that the State failed to prove 
  a sufficient chain of custody.Â  The rebriefing order further noted that the 
  chain of custody was the only issue of colorable merit.
After reviewing the record, briefs of 
  counsel, and applicable case law, we affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, 
  and the following authorities:Â  State v. Carter, 344 S.C. 419, 424, 544 
  S.E.2d 835, 837 (2001) (â€œ[W]here there is a weak link in the chain of custody, 
  as opposed to a missing link, the question is only one of credibility and not 
  admissibility.â€); State v. Williams, 297 S.C. 290, 293, 376 S.E.2d 773, 
  774 (1989) (holding the chain of custody of the defendantâ€™s blood sample that 
  was used for a blood alcohol test was sufficiently established through the introduction 
  of an initialed form that complied with hospital protocol and the testing nurseâ€™s 
  testimony, notwithstanding that the nurse who actually drew the blood did not 
  testify); and State v. Taylor, 360 S.C. 18,25, 27, 598 S.E.2d 735, 737 
  (Ct. App. 2004) (en banc) (holding that â€œ[i]f the identity of each person in 
  the chain handling the evidence is established, and the manner of handling is 
  reasonably demonstrated, no abuse of discretion is shown in the admission, absent 
  proof of tampering, bad faith, or ill-motiveâ€ and overruling Chisolm 
  to the extent that the decision requires the testimony of each person in the 
  chain of custody under all circumstances). [1]   
 AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in deciding the issue 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rules 215 
    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.
