PREHEARING REPORT



THIS OPINION HAS 
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR
 RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN 
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Chase Randlyn Burnett, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-487
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  September 21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Deputy Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald 
  J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia; and 
  Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

  
PER CURIAM:Â  Chase Randlyn Burnett appeals 
  her transfer from family court to circuit court and her conviction for murder.Â  
  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
On September 21, 1998, Jonathan Burnett found his 
  mother, Robin Burnett, dead in her bedroom.Â  Police officers discovered Robin 
  had a single gunshot wound to the head and a gun in her hand, giving the initial 
  appearance of suicide.Â  Officers also determined Robin had most likely died 
  on the night of September 20.Â  Almost immediately, officers were concerned with 
  the odd position of the gun in Robinâ€™s hand and focused their investigation 
  on Chase Burnett, Robinâ€™s fifteen-year-old daughter.Â  
Alan Wood and Tim Tucker, of the Spartanburg sheriffâ€™s 
  department, questioned Chase.Â  After waiving her rights, Chase made two statements 
  to the police.Â  In her first statement, she denied any knowledge of her motherâ€™s 
  death and stated she spent the day of September 21 with her friends.Â  However, 
  in her second statement, made approximately one and a half hours after the first, 
  she recalled a nightmare where her mother pointed a gun at her father and herself.Â  
  Chase stated she then woke up in her motherâ€™s room, retrieved a gun from under 
  the bed, and pulled the trigger.Â  
Chase was charged with murdering her mother in 
  a juvenile proceeding in the family court; however, the family court transferred 
  jurisdiction to the circuit court, where Chase was tried and convicted of murder.Â  
  The circuit court sentenced Chase to forty years.Â  The court noted credible 
  evidence of a history of criminal domestic violence pursuant to Section 16-25-90 
  of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003), which makes Chase eligible for parole 
  after serving one-fourth of her sentence.Â  Chase appeals her transfer to circuit 
  court and her conviction for murder.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
  â€œThe appellate court will affirm a transfer order 
    unless the family court has abused its discretion.â€Â  State v. Avery, 333 
    S.C. 284, 292, 509 S.E.2d 476, 481 (1998).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs 
    when the conclusions of the trial court either lack evidentiary support or 
    are controlled by an error of law.Â  State v. Wise, 359 S.C. 14, 21, 
    596 S.E.2d 475, 478 (2004).
  LAW/ANALYSIS
  Chase appeals her 
    conviction on the grounds that the family court judgeâ€™s transfer order was 
    conclusory and without a sufficient factual basis.Â  We disagree.
  Section 20-7-7605(5) of the South Carolina Code 
    (Supp. 2003) allows transfer of jurisdiction over minors ages fourteen and 
    fifteen charged with a serious felony, if after full investigation and a hearing, 
    the family court determines it is contrary to the interest of the child or 
    public to retain jurisdiction.Â  In Kent v. United States, 383 U.S. 
    541 (1966), the United States Supreme Court enunciated eight factors for the 
    family court to consider when transferring a juvenile from family court to 
    circuit court.Â  In a recent case, our supreme court reiterated those factors:

  1.Â  The seriousness of the alleged offense to the community 
    and whether the protection of the community requires waiver.Â  
  2.Â  Whether the alleged offense was committed in an aggressive, 
    violent, premeditated, or willful manner.Â  
  3.Â  Whether the alleged offense was against persons or against 
    property, greater weight being given to offenses against persons especially 
    if injury resulted.Â  
  4.Â  The prosecutive merit of the complaint, i.e., whether 
    there is evidence upon which a Grand Jury may be expected to return an indictmentâ€¦.Â  
  
  5.Â  The desirability of trial and disposition of the entire 
    offense in one court when the juvenile's associates in the alleged offense 
    are adults who will be charged with a crimeâ€¦.Â  
  6.Â  The sophistication and maturity of the juvenile as determined 
    by consideration of his home, environmental situation, emotional attitude 
    and pattern of living.Â  
  7.Â  The record and previous [criminal or adjudicative] history 
    of the juvenileâ€¦.Â  
  8.Â  The prospects for adequate protection of the public and 
    the likelihood of reasonable rehabilitation of the juvenile (if he is found 
    to have committed the alleged offense) by the use of procedures, services 
    and facilities currently available to the Juvenile Court.

  State v. Corey D., 339 S.C. 107, 117 n.4, 
    529 S.E.2d 20, 26 n.4 (2000) (quoting Kent, 383 U.S. at 566-67). 
  
  The family court 
    order that transferred jurisdiction over Chase to the circuit court contained 
    findings of facts regarding all of the Kent factors.Â  Chase argues 
    some of these findings were not supported by evidence and the courtâ€™s findings 
    were conclusory.  
  Chase specifically addresses the eighth 
    Kent factor, and claims the family courtâ€™s finding that â€œa prospect 
    of rehabilitation within the juvenile system is not goodâ€ is unsupported by 
    the record.Â  However, this finding of fact does have evidentiary support.Â  
    While Chaseâ€™s mental health diagnosis was in dispute, there was a consensus 
    that she had serious mental health problems. 
    [2] Â  The issue represented by the eighth Kent factor is whether 
    a family court sentence would offer sufficient time in the Department of Juvenile 
    Justice for Chase to be rehabilitated.Â  See Sanders v. State, 
    281 S.C. 53, 56, 314 S.E.2d 319, 321 (1984) (stating the serious nature 
    of the offense is a major factor in the transfer decision, especially where 
    a family court sentence cannot extend past the twenty-first birthday, whereas 
    the circuit court can impose an adult term sentence).
  Several expert witnesses testified 
    at the transfer hearing.Â  Two psychiatrists and a psychologist testified for 
    the defense and thought it would be appropriate for the Department of Juvenile 
    Justice to rehabilitate Chase, yet none could guarantee rehabilitation under 
    the maximum juvenile detention time frame.Â  The Department of Juvenile Justice 
    psychiatrist also could not determine with a reasonable degree of medical 
    certainty whether his department could rehabilitate Chase within the time 
    frame.Â  The evidence of rehabilitation was inconclusive at best.Â  
  Furthermore, evidence indicated 
    that the prospect of rehabilitation prior to Chaseâ€™s twenty-first birthday 
    or confinement release date was unlikely.Â  Chase had ten infractions in the 
    Department of Juvenile Justice that showed â€œoppositional behavior.â€Â  This 
    resistance to authority was also demonstrated by Chaseâ€™s decision to quit 
    taking medication despite the treating physicianâ€™s advice to the contrary.Â  
    Evidence concerning Chaseâ€™s resistance to authority undermines her ability 
    to be rehabilitated within the short time period that a family court sentence 
    would provide and supports the family courtâ€™s decision to transfer jurisdiction 
    to the circuit court.Â  
  Additionally, Chase argues 
    the transfer order was conclusory and it was the responsibility of the family 
    court to include a sufficient statement of reasons for, and considerations 
    leading to, its decision.Â  See In re Sullivan, 274 S.C. 544, 
    548, 265 S.E.2d 527, 529 (1980).Â  The family courtâ€™s transfer order, however, 
    when paired with the extensive hearing transcript, shows Chase is not deprived 
    of this courtâ€™s meaningful review of the decision.Â  Id. 274 S.C. at 
    547-48, 265 S.E.2d at 529.Â  Instead, the entire record demonstrates the family 
    court devoted substantial time and consideration to this issue.Â  In light 
    of evidence supporting the family courtâ€™s decision, we find no error in the 
    family courtâ€™s order.
  AFFIRMED.
  STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â  A defense expert diagnosed Chase as suffering from post-traumatic 
    stress disorder and secondary depression whereas the state psychiatrist diagnosed 
    her with depression, features of borderline personality disorder, and adjustment 
    and anxiety disorders.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Exide Corporation, and Johnson Controls, Inc.,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Bush's Recycling, Inc.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-489
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed September 21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Edward L. Graham, of Florence, for Appellant.
E. Lloyd Willcox, II, of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action to enforce the 
  judgment of an Alabama court, the appellant challenges the trial courtâ€™s determination 
  regarding personal jurisdiction and the validity of service of process.Â  We 
  affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Following an investigation by the Environmental 
  Protection Agency into the illegal dumping of hazardous substances at a smelting 
  and battery recycling facility located in Leeds, Alabama, Exide Corporation 
  and Johnson Controls, Inc. (â€œRespondentsâ€), along with others, entered into 
  a consent decree with the United States government.Â  The consent decree obligated 
  the signatories to finance and perform cleanup at the site and also to reimburse 
  the United States for past and future costs associated with cleanup.Â  As provided 
  for by federal law, Respondents sought contribution from more than one hundred 
  entities also identified as potentially liable for the contamination at the 
  Leeds facility.Â  Among those identified by Respondents was Bushâ€™s Recycling 
  (â€œAppellantâ€), a corporation with its principal place of business in Florence, 
  South Carolina.
Respondents brought suit in the United 
  States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, Southern Division, 
  against Appellant and all others from whom contribution was sought.Â  To initiate 
  the contribution proceedings, Respondents mailed Appellant a request to sign 
  a waiver of service notification.Â  Though Appellantâ€™s president, George Bush, 
  read the request, he declined to waive service.Â  Respondents then hired a professional 
  process server, Charles Ward, to effectuate formal service.Â  Ward personally 
  served the Summons and Complaint on an employee named Areece Myers on August 
  27, 1999 in Florence, South Carolina.Â  
 When Appellant failed to answer or otherwise 
  defend against the Complaint, Respondents moved for default judgment pursuant 
  to Rule 55(b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  On November 19, 1999, 
  the federal court granted the motion, issuing a default judgment against Appellant 
  in the amount of $80,696.
Seeking to enforce the Alabama judgment against 
  Appellant, Respondents filed a Notice of Foreign Judgment in the Florence County 
  Court of Common Pleas on August 2, 2001, and served the same on Appellant seven 
  days later.Â  In response, Appellant filed a Notice of Defenses, contending that 
  service of process was ineffectual and the federal court in Alabama lacked personal 
  jurisdiction over Appellant.Â  In addition, Appellant asserted defenses on the 
  merits, requested relief from the judgment on account of â€œmistake, inadvertence, 
  surprise or excusable neglect,â€ and argued the district court should have held 
  a hearing to ascertain damages.
Following a hearing on the matter, the 
  trial court rejected Appellantâ€™s defenses and ordered the Alabama judgment be 
  given full effect in South Carolina.Â  Appellant then filed a motion to amend 
  the judgment, which the trial court denied.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Personal Jurisdiction
Appellant contends the trial court erred in determining 
  Appellant had sufficient contacts with Alabama to bring Appellant within the 
  district courtâ€™s personal jurisdiction.Â  We disagree.
In accordance with the full faith and credit clause 
  of the United States Constitution, the courts of one state must give such force 
  and effect to a foreign judgment as the judgment would receive in the state 
  where rendered.Â  U.S. Const. Art. IV, Â§ 1; Carson v. Vance, 326 S.C. 
  543, 550, 485 S.E.2d 126, 130 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  At the same time, however, the 
  full faith and credit clause only binds a court to enforce the judgment if the 
  issuing court had jurisdiction to render the judgment.Â  Carson, 326 S.C. 
  at 548.Â  Thus, â€œ[a] defendant is always free to ignore the judicial proceedings, 
  risk a default judgment, and then challenge that judgment on jurisdictional 
  grounds in a collateral proceeding.â€Â  Ins. Corp. of Ireland, Ltd. v. Compagnie 
  des Bauxites de Guinee, 456 U.S. 694, 706 (1982).
â€œThe question of personal jurisdiction over a nonresident 
  defendant is one which must be resolved upon the facts of each particular case.Â  
  The decision of the trial court should be affirmed unless unsupported by the 
  evidence or influenced by an error of law.â€Â  Moosally v. W.W. Norton & 
  Co., Inc., 358 S.C. 320, 327, 594 S.E.2d 878, 882 (Ct. App. 2004) (citations 
  omitted).
The determination of whether a court may exercise 
  personal jurisdiction over a nonresident involves a two-step analysis: (1) the 
  nonresidentâ€™s conduct must meet the requirements of the stateâ€™s long-arm statute 
  and (2) the exercise of jurisdiction must comport with the requirements of the 
  due process clause.Â  Southern Plastics Co. v. Southern Commerce Bank, 
  310 S.C. 256, 259, 423 S.E.2d 128, 130 (1992).Â  Like those of many other states, 
  Alabamaâ€™s long-arm statute is construed to extend jurisdiction over nonresident 
  defendants to the full extent permitted by the due process clause.Â  Sieber 
  v. Campbell, 810 So.2d 641, 643-44 (Ala. 2001).Â  As a consequence, the two-part 
  jurisdictional analysis collapses into a single inquiry as to whether the defendant 
  had â€œminimal contactsâ€ with the forum state such that â€œmaintenance of the suit 
  does not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice.â€Â  
  Intâ€™l Shoe Co. v. Washington, 326 U.S. 310, 316 (1945); see also 
  Marbury v. Am. Truetzschler, 111 F. Supp. 2d 1281, 1283 (M.D. Ala. 2000) 
  (â€œâ€˜When the courts of the forum State have interpreted the forumâ€™s long-arm 
  statute to confer jurisdiction to the limits allowed by federal due process, 
  state law need not be applied: [the court] need only ask whether the exercise 
  of jurisdiction over the nonresident defendant comports with due process.â€™â€ 
  (citing Vermeulen v. Renault U.S.A., Inc., 975 F.2d 746, 753 (11th Cir. 
  1992)).
We find such minimum contacts exist.Â  On at least 
  seven occasions, Appellant shipped lead-spent batteries to a company named International 
  Lead Company in Leeds, Alabama.Â  Although Appellant delivered the batteries 
  through an intermediary, Appellantâ€™s invoices reveal that it was purposefully 
  directing a product of its recycling business to a specific location in Alabama.Â  
  Additionally, exercise of personal jurisdiction over Appellant does not offend 
  â€œtraditional notions of fair play and substantial justice.â€Â  Intâ€™l Shoe, 
  326 U.S. at 316.Â  In the course of participating in an industry that regularly 
  implicates commerce between and among multiple states, Appellant voluntarily 
  conducted business with Alabama, thereby invoking the protection of its laws.Â  
  In this manner, notions of fair play and substantial justice are both rightfully 
  served in requiring Appellant to answer in an Alabama court for any tortious 
  acts committed there.Â  Accordingly, the trial court correctly determined the 
  Alabama courtâ€™s exercise of personal jurisdiction over Appellant was proper.
II.Â  Service of Process
Appellant contends the trial court erred in determining 
  the Respondentâ€™s personal service of process on Myers was proper service on 
  the corporation.Â  We disagree.
â€œQuestions of fact arising on a motion to quash 
  service of process for lack of jurisdiction over the defendant are to be determined 
  by the court.Â  The findings of the [trial] court on such issues are binding 
  on the appellate court unless wholly unsupported by the evidence or manifestly 
  influenced or controlled by error of law.â€Â  Brown v. Carolina Emergency Physicians, 
  P.A., 348 S.C. 569, 583, 560 S.E.2d 624, 631 (Ct. App. 2001) (citations 
  omitted).
As outlined by both the Federal Rules of Civil 
  Procedure and the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, service of process 
  serves two purposes:Â  it confers personal jurisdiction on the court and it assures 
  the defendant has reasonable notice of the action.Â  Roche v. Young Bros., 
  Inc., of Florence, 318 S.C. 207, 209, 456 S.E.2d 897, 899 (1995).Â  Our courts 
  have never predicated effective service of process on exacting compliance with 
  the rules.Â  Rather, we inquire as to whether the plaintiff has sufficiently 
  complied with the rules as to confer personal jurisdiction and provide the defendant 
  with notice of the proceedings.Â  Id. at 210, 456 S.E.2d at 899.
Like its federal counterpart, Rule 4(d)(1), SCRCP, 
  provides for service upon an agent only if authorized by appointment or by law.Â  
  In determining whether an alleged agent has authority to receive process for 
  a defendant, we â€œmust look to the circumstances surrounding the relationship 
  and find authority which is either express or implied from the type of relationship 
  between the defendant and the alleged agent.â€Â  Moore v. Simpson, 322 
  S.C. 518, 523, 473 S.E.2d 64, 67 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Here, Myers has been employed 
  by Appellant for approximately twenty years and regularly deals with the public.Â  
  Moreover, Myers, Appellantâ€™s sole office employee, told the process server he 
  was authorized to accept service.Â  These circumstances imply Myers was authorized 
  to receive service.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court committed no error 
  in finding Respondentâ€™s personal service on Myers was reasonably calculated 
  to notify Appellant of the action.
AFFIRMED. [2]         
STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2] Â  Appellant also asserts the circuit 
    court erred by not relieving it from the Alabama judgment based on excusable 
    neglect, the existence of a defense on the merits, and ostensible invalidity 
    of the federal courtâ€™s default procedures.Â  These arguments are not available 
    to a defendant who is collaterally attacking a foreign judgment.Â  Milliken, 
    311 U.S. at 462 (â€œ[T]he full faith and credit clause of the Constitution precludes 
    any inquiry into the merits of the cause of action, the logic or consistency 
    of the decision, or the validity of the legal principles on which the judgment 
    is based.â€).Â  Because these issues are not properly before this Court, we 
    do not address them.

  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT

The State,

Roger A. Stevens,

William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-494
Submitted September 14, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  September 22, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McMaster, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  Roger A. Stevens appeals 
  his convictions of murder and first-degree burglary.Â  His complaint centers 
  on the solicitorâ€™s opening statement.Â  He argues the trial judge should have 
  more fully sustained his objection to the statement or should have declared 
  a mistrial.Â  We affirm. [1] 
In his opening statement, the solicitor 
  said the following:

Mr. Bankston Derrick had devoted 
  most of his life to the service of others.Â  He lived in Saluda County.Â  He worked 
  in the school system.Â  He had reached that point in life that all that hard 
  work would be rewarded in retirement.Â  He was in his mid-sixties.

Defense counsel objected.Â  
After the trial judge sent the jury to its room, 
  defense counsel argued:

The defense objects that the 
  State has gone into the victimâ€™s character and what a great person he was and 
  how much he did for the community and what a great service to the community 
  he was.Â  None of that is admissible.Â  Itâ€™s all prejudicial.Â  Itâ€™s appealing 
  to the passion and prejudice of the jury and just telling them what a great 
  hero this guy was, and it has nothing to do with the issues which are who killed 
  him.Â  

Defense counsel also moved for a mistrial.Â Â Â  
The trial judge ruled the objection was â€œsustained 
  in part and overruled in partâ€ and denied the â€œmotion for mistrial in full.â€Â  
  When the jury returned to the courtroom, the trial judge stated that the objection 
  had been â€œsustained in part; overruled in part.â€Â  The solicitor then told the 
  jurors where the victim had lived and continued his opening statement. 
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Regarding the question 
  of whether the trial judge should have more fully sustained the objection of 
  Stevens to the solicitorâ€™s opening statement, the issue is not preserved.Â  Defense 
  counsel never asked the trial judge to explain which part of the objection he 
  had sustained and which part he had overruled.Â  See State v. Adams, 
  354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding arguments not raised to 
  or ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review).
 2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  As to the question of whether 
  the trial judge should have declared a mistrial because of the solicitorâ€™s remarks, 
  we find no abuse of its discretion in this instance because the defendant failed 
  to demonstrate prejudice.Â  See State v. Cooper, 334 S.C. 540, 
  514 S.E.2d 584 (1999) (holding the question of whether to grant or deny a mistrial 
  is within the sound discretion of the trial court and its ruling will not be 
  disturbed on appeal unless an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law 
  occurs); State v. Harris, 340 S.C. 59, 530 S.E.2d 626 (2000) (holding 
  a mistrial should be granted only when absolutely necessary and to receive a 
  mistrial the defendant must show error and resulting prejudice).Â  The solicitorâ€™s 
  opening statement could not have prejudiced Stevens because evidence, to which 
  Stevens did not object, supported each of the solicitorâ€™s challenged remarks.Â  
  Cf. St. Louis-San Francisco Rwy. Co. v. King, 278 P.2d 845 (Okla. 
  1954) (permitting the plaintiffâ€™s counsel, over objection, to disclose in his 
  opening statement that the plaintiff had a wife and two minor children, to introduce 
  proof to that effect, and to refer in his closing argument to the plaintiffâ€™s 
  family responsibilities, the court stating that if there was any error it was 
  not prejudicial because the defendant voluntarily introduced three sworn statements 
  containing testimony of substantially the same character as that objected to), 
  abrogated on other grounds, Garrett v. Union 
  Pac. R.R., 828 P.2d 994 (Okla Ct. App. 1992).
As to the statement â€œMr. Bankston Derrick had devoted 
  most of his life to the service of others,â€ George Todd testified he had known 
  the victim since 1964 when he was Toddâ€™s sixth and seventh grade teacher and 
  Annette Derrick, the victimâ€™s sister, testified the victim was a retired elementary 
  school principal, an organist for two churches, and a part-time worker in a 
  church office.Â  
As to the statement â€œHe lived in Saluda County,â€ 
  Chief Deputy Charles Collard testified the victimâ€™s residence lay in Saluda 
  County while the victimâ€™s sister testified the victim lived two-tenths of a 
  mile from her house.Â  
As to the statement â€œHe worked in the school system,â€ 
  the victimâ€™s sister, as noted above, testified the victim had retired as an 
  elementary school principal.Â  
As to the statement â€œHe had reached that point 
  in life that all that hard work would be rewarded in retirement,â€ the victimâ€™s 
  sister, again as noted above, testified the victim had retired after serving 
  as an elementary school principal.Â  
As to the statement â€œHe was in his mid-sixties,â€ 
  the victimâ€™s sister testified her brother was â€œmaybe 66â€ years old. 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and WILLIAMS, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court 
    in resolving the issue on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument 
    pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        Walter McQueen, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        Staffmark, Inc. and Atlantic 
          Mutual Insurance Co., Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chesterfield 
  County
  Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion 
  No. 2004-UP-495
  Submitted September 15, 2004 
  â€“ Filed September 30, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        Stanford E. Lacy, Christian 
          Stegmaier, Collins & Lacy, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Kenneth Ray Martin, Martin 
          Law Offices, of Cheraw, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER 
  CURIAM: StaffMark, Inc. and Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company (collectively 
  StaffMark) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s reversal of the Appellate Panel of the 
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s order denying claimant Walter McQueen compensation.Â  
  We reverse. 1Â  
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL 
  BACKGROUND
McQueen was hired by StaffMark, a 
  company that provides temporary employees to other businesses, around January 
  11, 1999.Â  He was assigned to the Wal-Mart Distribution Center, where he worked 
  as an order filler.Â  
David 
  Kessler, who had been McQueenâ€™s StaffMark supervisor, testified by deposition 
  that soon after McQueen began working, the manager at Wal-Mart wanted McQueen 
  let go because of poor work performance.Â  On Monday, January 25, 1999, Kessler 
  informed McQueen that his assignment at Wal-Mart was complete, which is the 
  terminology StaffMark used rather than stating someoneâ€™s employment was terminated.Â  
  Kessler stated that he told McQueen to turn in all of his equipment.Â  He also 
  advised McQueen that if he went to the StaffMark office in Monroe, North Carolina, 
  that office might be able to find another job for him.Â  
Kessler 
  testified that about thirty minutes later, McQueen and his Wal-Mart supervisor 
  approached him.Â  The supervisor advised Kessler that McQueen had just told him 
  that McQueen had hurt his back.Â  In response to Kesslerâ€™s questioning, McQueen 
  stated he had hurt his back during his Thursday shift, which was the last night 
  he had worked.Â  Kessler stated McQueenâ€™s failure to notify his supervisor immediately 
  of the injury was in violation of StaffMarkâ€™s policies.Â  He explained that he 
  had given copies of StaffMarkâ€™s injury reports to the loss prevention office 
  and had requested that in case of an injury to a StaffMark employee when he 
  or the other StaffMark supervisor was not there, that the forms be filled out 
  and he or StaffMark employee Renee Haigler be called.Â  Kessler averred that 
  the first he heard of McQueenâ€™s injury was after he had terminated McQueenâ€™s 
  employment.Â  
In contrast 
  to Kesslerâ€™s testimony, McQueen testified that immediately after he felt â€œsomething 
  popâ€ in his back, he went to Michael Reese, a supervisor for the Wal-Mart Distribution 
  Center and explained to him what happened.Â  The accident happened in the early 
  morning hours of Friday, January 22, 1999.Â  He finished working that night and 
  went home around 3:30 a.m.Â  He went back to work the afternoon of Monday, January 
  25, 1999.Â  As soon as he arrived at the Distribution Center, he spoke again 
  with Reese.Â  Reese took him to the StaffMark supervisor whom McQueen called 
  â€œMr. Mullins.â€Â  McQueen testified Mullins informed them, â€œNo, you donâ€™t have 
  to fill out an accident report on him cause Iâ€™m gone (sic) let him go anyway.â€Â  
  McQueen related Mullins then told him to turn in his equipment.Â  McQueen maintained 
  he had told Mullins about his injury before Mullins terminated his employment.Â  
  
McQueen 
  had x-rays taken at Chesterfield General Hospital and sought treatment from 
  Dr. Thrailkill and the other doctors in that practice for four months until 
  he was released to return to work.Â  He stated the doctors referred him to a 
  specialist, but he did not see the specialist because he did not have the money 
  to pay for such a visit.Â  He is still bothered by the injury.Â  
McQueen 
  filed a claim for Workersâ€™ Compensation benefits.Â  StaffMark denied the claim.Â  
  The single commissioner held McQueen had suffered a compensable injury and ordered 
  StaffMark to be responsible for all authorized medical treatment through the 
  date of maximum medical improvement.Â  The commissioner ruled any finding as 
  to permanent impairment or disability was premature, as McQueen had not yet 
  reached maximum medical improvement.Â  
The Appellate 
  Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission reversed the order of the single 
  commissioner.Â  It listed the inconsistencies between McQueenâ€™s hearing testimony 
  and information he gave during his job application, doctorâ€™s visits, and deposition 
  testimony.Â  It noted that Kessler, who had left StaffMarkâ€™s employment and was 
  a military chaplain stationed in Germany, had no stake in the outcome of the 
  case.Â  It found Kessler to be the more credible witness and the one worthy of 
  belief while McQueenâ€™s testimony was not worthy of belief because of his omissions 
  inconsistencies, and misrepresentations.Â  The Appellate Panel held, â€œLooking 
  at the record as a whole, because claimantâ€™s testimony is not worthy of belief, 
  and there is no other evidence of accident or injury, the commissionâ€™s Order 
  should be reversed.â€
The circuit 
  court reversed the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision, reinstated the single commissionerâ€™s 
  order, and remanded the matter to the Appellate Panel for a determination of 
  the specific benefits due McQueen.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
STANDARD 
  OF REVIEW
The Administrative 
  Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South 
  Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, 276 S.C. 130, 
  135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  This court can reverse or modify the Appellate 
  Panelâ€™s decision only if the appellantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced 
  because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous 
  in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  
  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 454, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2003).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not 
  a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, 
  when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach 
  the conclusion the [Appellate Panel] reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 
  535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions 
  does not prevent the Appellate Panelâ€™s conclusions from being supported by substantial 
  evidence.Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d 
  843, 845 (1999).
The Appellate 
  Panel is the ultimate fact finder in workersâ€™ compensation cases and is not 
  bound by the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Ross v. American Red 
  Cross, 298 S.C. 490, 492, 381 S.E.2d 728, 730 (1989).Â  â€œThe final determination 
  of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to 
  the [Appellate Panel].Â  It is not the task of this Court to weigh the evidence 
  as found by the [Appellate Panel].â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d 
  at 442 (citations omitted).
DISCUSSION
StaffMark 
  argues the circuit court erred in reversing the decision of the Appellate Panel.Â  
  We agree.Â  
Kessler and 
  McQueen presented competing versions about how McQueen reported his injury.Â  
  McQueen stated he immediately told his Wal-Mart supervisor about the injury 
  when it occurred Friday morning and that he and the supervisor told the StaffMark 
  supervisor about the injury at the beginning of McQueenâ€™s Monday shift, before 
  he was fired.Â  Kessler, on the other hand, testified that it was not until thirty 
  minutes after he fired McQueen that McQueen and the Wal-Mart supervisor approached 
  him to report the injury.Â  Furthermore, according to Kessler, the Wal-Mart supervisor 
  stated that McQueen had just told him about the injury.Â  
The Appellate 
  Panel found Kessler to be more credible as he was no longer employed by StaffMark 
  and thus had no stake in the matter.Â  The Panel further found McQueen to be 
  not worthy of belief.Â  It noted that while McQueen had listed on his employment 
  application at StaffMark that he had been employed by a trucking company in 
  Virginia for thirty years, he testified at the hearing that he had worked a 
  number of different places.Â  The Panel described how McQueen had been inconsistent 
  in his deposition and hearing testimony concerning previous workersâ€™ compensation 
  claims.Â  Although he testified in his deposition that he had no prior workersâ€™ 
  compensation claims, at the hearing he admitted to a claim in Virginia.Â  The 
  Panel noted that McQueen had been inconsistent regarding his symptoms, testifying 
  at the hearing that he had back pain with pain radiating down the right leg 
  only, while describing bilateral leg pain at his initial doctorâ€™s visit.Â  The 
  Appellate Panel related how during McQueenâ€™s hearing testimony he denied filing 
  workersâ€™ compensation claims against a subsequent employer but recanted when 
  challenged and acknowledged two workersâ€™ compensation claims against Powell 
  Manufacturing.Â  It noted that when McQueen sought treatment for the hand injury 
  that was the basis of his claim against Powell, he told the emergency room staff 
  that he had just been terminated.Â  He also told them he had consumed half a 
  pint of liquor.Â  At the hearing, he denied both of these statements.Â  
The Appellate 
  Panel found McQueenâ€™s testimony was directly refuted by Kesslerâ€™s and it was 
  not possible to believe both witnesses.Â  It concluded McQueenâ€™s testimony was 
  not worthy of belief because of his omissions, inconsistencies, and misrepresentations.Â  
  
The circuit 
  court rejected the Appellate Panelâ€™s determination of the credibility of the 
  witnesses.Â  It explained that the single commissioner had the opportunity to 
  observe McQueenâ€™s testimony and demeanor and such opportunity allowed her to 
  accurately gauge his credibility.Â  On the other hand, the court noted, no one 
  had the opportunity to personally observe the demeanor of Kessler, who testified 
  by international telephone deposition, and thereby evaluate his credibility.Â  
  However, as stated above, issues of witness credibility are for the Appellate 
  Panel to decide, not for this court or the circuit court to decide.Â  See 
  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).
The circuit 
  court found that objective medical findings in the file substantiated McQueenâ€™s 
  claim of injury.Â  However, even in McQueenâ€™s medical records, the only evidence 
  that he was injured while working for StaffMark was provided by McQueen himself 
  in his statements to the doctor.Â  The Appellate Panel acted within its authority 
  in discounting any statements by McQueen, whom it found to be not worthy of 
  belief.Â  Absent any statements or testimony from McQueen, the record is devoid 
  of any evidence of an injury by accident while McQueen was working for StaffMark, 
  as the Appellate Panel found.Â  Accordingly, we hold the circuit court erred 
  in reversing the decision of the Appellate Panel.Â Â  Thus, the order of the circuit 
  court is REVERSED and the decision of the Appellate Panel reinstated.Â  
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and KITTREDGE, 
  JJ., concur.
   

 
  1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Bruce S. Skinner, M.D.,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Trident Medical Center, L.L.C., Successor to North Trident Regional Hospital, 
        Inc. and Cheryl Aloway,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-496
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed September 30, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gregg E. Meyers, of Charleston, for Appellant.
C. Mitchell Brown, Elizabeth H. Campbell, of Columbia; M. 
  Dawes Cook, Lucinda Wichmann, and Wendy J. Keefer, all of Charleston, for Respondent
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from an order 
  granting respondents, Trident Medical Center, L.L.C. and Cheryl Aloway, a new 
  trial absolute following a jury verdict for Dr. Bruce Skinner on claims of defamation, 
  negligent supervision, and conversion.Â  We affirm.  
  [1] 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This action arose out of certain events Dr. Skinner 
  alleged occurred in connection with his employment as an internist with Trident 
  Medical Center, L.L.C.Â  Dr. Skinner began his employment with Trident on January 
  5, 1998 in an office in St. Stephen, South Carolina.Â  Originally, Trident planned 
  to keep Dr. Skinner at the St. Stephen office only a short time, and thereafter 
  relocate him to a new office in the Crowfield area.Â  According to Trident, due 
  to market factors and structural problems with the facility, Trident decided 
  to close the St. Stephen office.Â  Because of several changes in circumstances, 
  Trident needed the doctor at the Crowfield location to have hospital admitting 
  privileges.Â  Dr. Skinner did not have those privileges, and Trident decided 
  to terminate Dr. Skinnerâ€™s employment per its standard contract allowing sixty 
  days notice for termination without cause.Â  Dr. Skinner was provided with notice 
  in April 1998 and his position was terminated in June 1998.Â  
During the time Dr. Skinner worked in the St. Stephen 
  office he had conflicts with the area office manager, Cheryl Aloway, over office 
  issues such as billing and the condition of the office.Â  Following his termination, 
  Dr. Skinner was unsuccessful in finding employment as a physician.Â  Thereafter, 
  Dr. Skinner instituted this action against Trident and Aloway alleging, among 
  other things, that (1) Aloway made false, slanderous statements about Dr. Skinner, 
  (2) Trident negligently supervised Aloway, and (3) Trident had converted a patient 
  list Dr. Skinner had supplied to Trident to its own use and refused to return 
  the list to Dr. Skinner.Â  Dr. Skinner maintained his difficulty in obtaining 
  employment as a physician was due to malicious slander by Aloway, Tridentâ€™s 
  negligent supervision of Aloway, and conversion of a computer patient list of 
  Dr. Skinnerâ€™s.Â  Trident and Aloway asserted that Dr. Skinnerâ€™s inability to 
  find physician related employment was due to a number of factors including his 
  lack of admitting privileges and board certification, the fact that he was out 
  of work for a year and a half prior to his employment with Trident and had not 
  built up a network of relations with other doctors and hospitals, and the fact 
  that Dr. Skinnerâ€™s application letters gave indications to prospective employers 
  that he was unemployable.Â  
Dr. Skinnerâ€™s slander claim stems from statements 
  made by Aloway, who was an area manager for Trident overseeing eight separate 
  offices, including the St. Stephen office where Dr. Skinner worked.Â  Aloway 
  admittedly made statements to three other Trident employees that Dr. Skinner 
  was believed to have taken some equipment from the office that he was not supposed 
  to take, and that he had sabotaged the office by leaving water running in a 
  stopped-up sink overnight.Â  
Aloway testified as to what prompted her statements 
  that Dr. Skinner had sabotaged the office.Â  She stated Dr. Skinner was supposed 
  to fill in at the St. Stephen office while Trident awaited the arrival of a 
  doctor from Canada to take over that office.Â  At that time, the plan was then 
  to move Dr. Skinner to the Crowfield office.Â  However, the Canadian doctor had 
  trouble with his visa, possibly postponing his arrival by six months.Â  Dr. Skinner 
  had been complaining about the condition of the St. Stephen office, and expressed 
  concern that he would have to stay there and would never get to the Crowfield 
  office.Â  One of Alowayâ€™s superiors, Ian Watson, was scheduled to visit the St. 
  Stephen office to evaluate the condition of the building.Â  Around that time, 
  Dr. Skinner made a comment to Aloway concerning whether he should make the office 
  look worse than it actually was, in anticipation of Watsonâ€™s visit.Â  The night 
  before Watson was scheduled to come to the St. Stephan location, there was a 
  leak in the kitchen that flooded out into the hallway and onto the carpet.Â  
  When the plumber arrived, he could find nothing to have caused the leak, but 
  indicated he believed someone had intentionally stopped up the sink, let the 
  water runoff, and then unstopped it.Â  When Aloway talked to Dr. Skinner about 
  the leak, he indicated he felt the housekeeper had done it.Â  The housekeeper 
  denied having caused the leak, and told Aloway that when she left the building 
  that night, Dr. Skinner was still there.Â  Aloway theorized that if the St. Stephen 
  office were to close, Dr. Skinner would be able to get to the Crowfield location 
  sooner.Â  She thus came to the conclusion that, if anyone had caused the damage, 
  it was Dr. Skinner.Â  
As to the missing equipment, Aloway testified, 
  while Dr. Skinner had been authorized to take some equipment home with him, 
  she suspected he had taken some other equipment from the office for which he 
  had not received permission.Â  When she expressed these concerns to her superior, 
  she was told to simply call Dr. Skinner and ask him to bring the equipment back.Â  
  She was not to make a specific list of the items, but was to leave it up to 
  Dr. Skinnerâ€™s discretion as to what he would return.Â  Aloway arranged to have 
  the items returned to Tridentâ€™s Crowfield office.Â  When she went there to pick 
  up the equipment, she was surprised and frustrated to find only one small box 
  that did not contain all the items she had expected, and questioned the staff 
  as to whether that was all that was left there.Â  When the staff indicated that 
  was the extent of the returned items and then questioned Aloway, she expressed 
  to the three co-workers that Dr. Skinner had taken some things.Â  She further 
  admitted that she may have â€œblurted outâ€ that Dr. Skinner had also sabotaged 
  his office.Â  
Aloway also admitted she may have expressed her 
  beliefs regarding Dr. Skinner to another person after she was no longer employed 
  by Trident.Â  After leaving Trident in August 1998, Aloway went to work for an 
  association of independent physicians (IPA).Â  Dr. Bounds, who served on the 
  board of directors of IPA, received a call from Dr. Skinner, asking if Dr. Bounds 
  had heard Aloway say anything negative about him.Â  At that time, Aloway had 
  never mentioned Dr. Skinner to Dr. Bounds and Dr. Bounds informed Dr. Skinner 
  of this.Â  Thereafter, Dr. Bounds saw Aloway at an IPA meeting and asked her 
  what had occurred with Dr. Skinner.Â  Aloway then responded that Dr. Skinner 
  had stolen an EKG machine and had sabotaged the St. Stephen office.Â  Aloway 
  testified she only made this statement as a direct answer to an inquiry from 
  a board member who was her boss, and she would not have said anything about 
  it if it had not been raised in a question from her boss.Â  Aloway testified 
  that she still believed the statements she made about Dr. Skinner were true.Â  

Dr. Skinnerâ€™s conversion claim involves a list containing 
  potential patient contact information.Â  Dr. Skinner obtained this list of potential 
  patients in the summer of 1996, while he was employed at the Naval Hospital 
  in Charleston.Â  After he began his employment with Trident, Dr. Skinner gave 
  the list to Aloway so that announcements of his employment could be sent out.Â  
  Aloway testified she passed the list on to a secretary at Trident.Â  She further 
  stated that Trident had not requested the list, but Dr. Skinner had suggested 
  they use the list for the announcement and Trident agreed.Â  However, the list 
  ultimately was not used due to Dr. Skinnerâ€™s termination.Â  Dr. Skinner requested 
  return of the list when he was terminated, but the list was lost and Trident 
  was never able to locate it.Â  Trident and Aloway presented evidence that, because 
  the list was around two years old by the time Dr. Skinner left Trident and included 
  military personnel who likely had moved on, it was of little to no value.Â  They 
  further presented evidence that Dr. Skinner was not the rightful owner of the 
  list and that Trident had not used the list for its own benefit.Â  
The case was submitted to the jury under the causes 
  of action of slander, conversion, and negligent supervision.Â  Without objection, 
  the jury received instruction on the law of defamation which included statements 
  made under a qualified privilege [2]  and/or statements invited or procured by a plaintiff such that 
  the publication was insufficient to support an action for defamation. 
  [3] Â  The jury further received instruction on the law of conversion. [4] Â  
On December 19, 2002, the jury returned its verdict.Â  
  Originally, the juryâ€™s verdict was as follows: (a) for Dr. Skinner on the conversion 
  claim in the amount of $250,000.00 actual damages, (b) for Dr. Skinner against 
  Aloway individually on the defamation claim for $25,000.00 actual and $25,000.00 
  punitive damages, (c) for Dr. Skinner against both Aloway and Trident on the 
  defamation claim for $1 million actual and $10 million punitive damages, and 
  (d) for Dr. Skinner against Trident on the negligent supervision claim in the 
  amount of $10 million actual damages.Â  The court and the parties agreed that 
  actual damages could not differ for the defamation claim against Aloway and 
  the defamation claim against Trident, which was only vicariously liable.Â  In 
  addition, the court and the parties agreed it was illogical to award greater 
  damages for the defamation claim than the negligent supervision claim.Â  Accordingly, 
  the court instructed the jury to clarify its verdict on the defamation and negligent 
  supervision claims, but did not resubmit the conversion action to the jury.Â  
  When the jury returned after further instructions, it found for Dr. Skinner 
  in the amount of $10 million for negligent supervision against Trident, and 
  against both Trident and Aloway in the amount of $10 million actual damages 
  and $10 million punitive damages for slander.Â  Dr. Skinner subsequently elected 
  to recover the slander award rather than the negligent supervision award.Â  
In an order filed on June 23, 2003, the trial judge 
  exercised his discretion as the thirteenth juror and granted Trident and Aloway 
  a new trial.Â  He found the evidence did not support the verdicts and justice 
  had not prevailed.Â  In the alternative, the trial judge concluded a new trial 
  was warranted because the verdicts were so excessive as to indicate they were 
  the result of passion, prejudice, caprice, or some other influence outside the 
  evidence presented.Â  Dr. Skinner appeals the order granting a new trial.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Dr.
Skinner argues the trial court erred in finding the evidence did not justify the
verdicts on the conversion and defamation awards and therefore the order
granting a new trial under the thirteenth juror doctrine should be reversed. 
We disagree.


The
thirteenth juror doctrine is a vehicle by which the trial judge may grant a new
trial absolute when he finds that the evidence does not justify the verdict.  Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C. 251, 254, 387 S.E.2d 265,
267 (1990).  Such a ruling has also
been termed a granting of a new trial upon the facts.  Id.  The
trial judge has the authority to grant a new trial outright when, sitting as the
thirteenth juror charged with the duty of seeing that justice is done, he is
convinced that a new trial is necessitated on the basis of the facts in the
case.  Graham v. Whitaker,
282 S.C. 393, 401, 321 S.E.2d 40, 45 (1984). 
This doctrine is so named because it entitles the trial judge to sit, in
essence, as the thirteenth juror when he finds the evidence does not justify the
verdict, and then to grant a new trial based solely upon the facts. 
Norton v. Norfolk S. Ry. Co., 350 S.C. 473, 478, 567 S.E.2d 851,
854 (2002).  â€œ[T]he trial judge is
the thirteenth juror, possessing the veto power to the Nth degree, and, it must
be presumed, recognizes and appreciates his responsibility, and exercises the
discretion vested in him with fairness and impartiality.â€ 
Worrell v. South Carolina Power Co., 186 S.C. 306, 313-14, 195
S.E. 638, 641 (1938).  As the
thirteenth juror, the trial judge can hang the jury by refusing to agree to a
jury verdict that is otherwise unanimous.  Id. 
The effect is the same as if the jury failed to reach a verdict,
resulting in a new trial.  Folkens,
300 S.C. at 254, 387 S.E.2d at 267.  Neither
judge nor jury is required to give reasons for the outcome. 
Id.  Further, a trial
judgeâ€™s order granting or denying a new trial upon the facts will not be
disturbed unless his decision is wholly unsupported by the evidence, or the
conclusion reached was controlled by an error of law. 
Id.  
 

    As to the conversion claim, Dr. Skinner contends 
      the information contained in the patient list would have enabled him to 
      establish his own practice and the $250,000 award therefore was not excessive.Â  
      He further argues that, because the defamation was per se, 
      general damages are presumed, and that, along with evidence presented regarding 
      malicious actions by Trident and Aloway as well as Dr. Skinnerâ€™s resulting 
      unemployment and the intangible injuries suffered by him, justified the 
      award.Â  
    In reviewing the trial courtâ€™s decision to 
      grant a new trial under the thirteenth juror doctrine, this court does not, 
      however, look to whether the evidence presented below could support the 
      juryâ€™s verdict.Â  The granting of a new trial upon the facts is not the equivalent 
      of granting a directed verdict.Â  McEntire v. Mooregard Exterminating 
      Servs., Inc., 353 S.C. 629, 632, 578 S.E.2d 746, 748 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
      Unlike a directed verdict motion, in considering whether to grant a new 
      trial under the thirteenth juror doctrine, the trial judge weighs the evidence, 
      and he need not view it in a light most favorable to the opposing party.Â  
      Id.Â  Though the trial judge may be compelled to submit the issues 
      to the jury, it does not follow that he cannot subsequently grant a new 
      trial absolute under the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  Worrell, 186 
      S.C. at 313-14, 195 S.E. at 641.Â  Rather, our review is limited to consideration 
      of whether evidence exists to support the trial courtâ€™s order.Â  Folkens, 
      300 S.C. at 255, 387 S.E.2d at 267.Â  Unless the decision to grant a new 
      trial on the facts is wholly unsupported by the evidence or the trial judgeâ€™s 
      conclusion was controlled by an error of law, the order will not be disturbed 
      on appeal.Â  Id.Â  Where conflicting evidence exists on the contested 
      issues, â€œthe trial courtâ€™s ruling is not wholly unsupported by the evidence,â€ 
      and its decision will not be overturned.Â  Id. at 255, 387 S.E.2d 
      at 267.
    Under our limited scope of review, we cannot 
      say the courtâ€™s ruling is â€œwholly unsupported by the evidence.â€Â  Conflicting 
      evidence was presented by the parties as to whether the statements made 
      by Aloway were privileged and/or invited.Â  Further, the evidence was in 
      conflict as to whether Trident was properly excused from returning the patient 
      list to Dr. Skinner because the list was simply lost rather than intentionally 
      withheld, whether Dr. Sinner had title to or the right to possession of 
      the list, or whether the list had any value such that the failure to return 
      it resulted in any damage to Dr. Skinner.Â  Further, there is no indication, 
      and appellant does not argue, that the trial judge was controlled by an 
      error of law, such as the application of an incorrect standard.Â  Accordingly, 
      we find no error in the trial judgeâ€™s decision to grant a new trial pursuant 
      to the thirteenth juror doctrine 
      [5]  and the order below is
    AFFIRMED
    HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

   
    
    [1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
  
   
     
      [2] â€œA communication made in good faith on any subject matter in which 
      the person communicating has an interest or duty is qualifiedly privileged 
      if made to a person with a corresponding interest or duty even though it 
      contains matter which, without this privilege, would be actionable.â€Â  Murray 
      v. Holnam, Inc., 344 S.C. 129, 140-41, 542 S.E.2d 743, 749 (Ct. App. 
      2001).Â  â€œCommunications between officers and employees of a corporation 
      are qualifiedly privileged if made in good faith and in the usual course 
      of business.â€Â  Id.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
  
   
     
      [3] â€œIt is a sound principle of law that a person cannot invite or provoke 
      another to make a slanderous charge against him, and then sue such person 
      for damages on account of such charge.â€Â  Boling v. Clinton Cotton Mills, 
      163 S.C. 13, 24, 161 S.E. 195, 199 (1931).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
  
   
     
      [4] â€œConversion is the unauthorized assumption and exercise of the right 
      of ownership over goods or personal chattels belonging to another, to the 
      alteration of the condition or the exclusion of the ownerâ€™s rights.â€Â  Crane 
      v. Citicorp Natâ€™l Servs., Inc., 313 S.C. 70, 73, 437 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1993).Â  
      It is a wrongful act which emanates by either a wrongful taking or wrongful 
      detention.Â  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 667, 582 S.E.2d 
      432, 442 (Ct. App. 2003).Â Â  â€œTo establish the tort of conversion, it is 
      essential that the plaintiff establish either title to or right to the possession 
      of the personal property.â€Â  Crane, 313 S.C. at 73, 437 S.E.2d at 
      52.Â  
  
   
     
      [5] Because we affirm the trial judgeâ€™s order granting a new trial pursuant 
      to the thirteenth juror doctrine, we need not address Dr. Skinnerâ€™s assertion 
      that the trial judge also erred in his alternative ruling that a new trial 
      was warranted because the verdicts were so excessive as to indicate they 
      were the result of passion, prejudice, caprice, or some other influence 
      outside the evidence presented.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
       
        Travelers Home Mortgage Services, 
          Inc.,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        Johnel Mosley and Ernest Mosley,        
          Defendants,
        of whom Ernest Mosley is        
          Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
  Olin D. Burgdorf, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-497
  Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed September 30, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
       
        Edward D. Sullivan, of Columbia, 
          for Appellant.
        Louis H. Lang, and Demetri 
          K. Koutrakos, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 PER 
  CURIAM:  Travelers Home Mortgage 
  Services, Inc. brought this declaratory judgment action against Johnel Mosley 
  and Ernest Mosley seeking a declaration that a deed executed by Johnel as purported 
  attorney-in-fact for Ernest was valid.Â  The trial court found for Travelers 
  on its motions for default judgment and summary judgment.Â  We affirm. 1
FACTSÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  
The subject property is located at 
  1432 Pepper Lane, Orangeburg, South Carolina.Â  In 1985, Ellis and Son, Inc. 
  conveyed the property to Ernest and his wife, Shirley Mosley.Â  In 1995, Shirley 
  conveyed her interest in the property to her brother-in-law, Johnel, for $17,000.Â  

The deed at issue in this case was 
  executed on March 20, 1996.Â  The deed purported to convey Ernestâ€™s interest 
  in the property to Johnel.Â  It is signed by â€œErnest Moseley2 by Johnel Moseley attorney-in-fact 
  for Ernest Moseley.â€Â  Ernest was incarcerated in federal prison at the time 
  Johnel executed the 1996 deed.Â  
On April 23, 1996, Johnel executed 
  a mortgage on the property with Cityscape Corporation in the original principal 
  amount of $42,000.Â  Johnel subsequently refinanced the debt on the property 
  by executing a mortgage for $61,000 to Collinbrook Mortgage Corporation on January 
  23, 1998.Â  From the proceeds of the loan secured by this mortgage, Johnel paid 
  $42,000 to satisfy the Cityscape mortgage.Â  Collinbrook assigned the 1998 mortgage 
  to Travelers.Â  
Johnel defaulted on the loan secured 
  by the Travelers mortgage and Travelers foreclosed.Â  Travelers was the successful 
  bidder at the foreclosure sale and the master issued a masterâ€™s deed conveying 
  the property to Travelers.Â  
On May 29, 2001, Travelers filed the 
  present action against Johnel and Ernest seeking a declaratory judgment that 
  the 1996 deed executed by Johnel as attorney-in-fact for Ernest was valid and 
  conveyed the property in fee simple absolute to Johnel such that any interest 
  Ernest had in the property was extinguished.Â  Travelers served Johnel on July 
  28, 2001.Â  Johnel failed to file an answer, notice of appearance, or other pleading.Â  
  Travelers served Ernest on August 30, 2001, at the federal prison in Yazoo City, 
  Mississippi.Â  Ernest responded with a letter to Travelers that was filed with 
  the court.Â  In the letter Ernest stated that he was involved with Johnel in 
  a lawsuit over Johnelâ€™s illegal signing of Ernestâ€™s name.Â  
In October of 2001, Travelers filed 
  and served an amended complaint.Â  Neither Johnel nor Ernest answered; therefore, 
  Travelers filed affidavits of default.Â  Travelers filed a petition seeking a 
  guardian ad litem (GAL) appointment for Ernest pursuant to Rule 17(c), SCRCP,3 due to his incarceration.Â  Edward D. Sullivan was appointed GAL 
  for Ernest.Â  The GAL filed a motion to set aside Ernestâ€™s default and for leave 
  to file responsive pleadings.Â  The GAL also filed an answer to the amended complaint 
  with a counterclaim seeking a declaration that the subject property belonged 
  to Ernest.Â  Travelers filed a motion for default judgment against Ernest and 
  Johnel, or in the alternative, for default judgment against Johnel and for summary 
  judgment against Ernest.Â  The GAL filed a cross-motion for summary judgment.Â  

The trial court granted Travelersâ€™ 
  motion for default judgment, or alternatively, for summary judgment and denied 
  Ernestâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  The court also ruled as an alternative 
  Travelers would be entitled to equitable subrogation in the amount of $42,000, 
  which essentially operates as an equitable lien on Ernestâ€™s 50% undivided interest.Â  
  This appeal followed.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen reviewing the grant of a summary 
  judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs 
  the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there 
  is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled 
  to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Baril v. Aiken Regâ€™l Med. Ctrs., 352 
  S.C. 271, 279-80, 573 S.E.2d 830, 835 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The evidence should 
  be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id. at 
  280, 573 S.E.2d at 835.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Ernest argues the deed to Johnel was 
  void ab initio because there was no written, recorded power of attorney 
  granting Johnel authority to execute the deed.  Ernest is correct that 
  â€œa power of attorney should be evidenced by an instrument in writing.â€ In 
  the Matter of Celsor, 330 S.C. 497, 501, 499 S.E.2d 809, 811 (1998) (citing 
  3 Am.Jur. Agency Â§ 23 (1986)).  However, even if Johnel did not 
  act pursuant to a valid power of attorney in executing the deed as attorney-in-fact 
  for Ernest, Ernest ratified the transfer in his complaint in a lawsuit he filed 
  against Johnel, in which Ernest admitted he had agreed to transfer the property 
  to Johnel.  
One whose name has been signed to an instrument without 
authorization may ratify the signature and become bound thereby.  3 Am.Jur.2d 
Agency Â§ 188 (2002). Ratification, as it relates to the law of agency, 
means the express or implied adoption and confirmation by one person of an act 
or contract performed or entered into in his behalf by another who at the time 
assumed to act as his agent.  Lincoln v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co, 
300 S.C. 188, 191, 386 S.E.2d 801, 803 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  The three essential elements 
required to prove ratification are:Â  â€œ(1) acceptance by the principal of the benefits 
of the agentâ€™s acts; (2) full knowledge of the facts; and (3) circumstances or 
an affirmative election indicating an intention to adopt the unauthorized arrangements.â€Â  
Id. 
  
  On April 7, 2000, Ernest filed a pro se action against Johnel 
  alleging the following in his complaint: 
 
  22.Â  Around the beginning of 1996, 
    the Plaintiff Ernest Mosely, needing $10,000.00 to pay for some legal expenses, 
    arranged with the Defendant Johnel Mosely to obtain a $30,000.00 mortgage 
    on the Pepper Lane property.Â  Of this amount, $10,000.00 was to be given to 
    Ernest Mosely, $10,000.00 was to be distributed to Ernestâ€™s wife â€“ Shirley 
    Mosely, and Johnel Mosely was to keep $10,000.00 for himself.Â  
  23.  In order to facilitate 
    the obtaining of the mortgage and due to Ernest Moselyâ€™s incarceration, Ernest 
    Mosely agreed to transfer title to the Pepper Lane property to Johnel Mosely, 
    with Johnel Moselyâ€™s promise that when Ernest Mosely was released from incarceration, 
    Johnel Mosely would transfer title of the property back to Ernest Mosely.

Ernestâ€™s
complaint in the 2000 lawsuit clearly shows Ernest knew of the transfer of
property, approved it, and reaped the benefits of it. 
Ernest accepted the benefits of Johnelâ€™s act by receiving $10,000 for
himself and another $10,000 for his wife as a result of the Cityscape mortgage.  In addition, Ernestâ€™s 2000 complaint which states he
